In Galway, 600 people are on the waiting list who have been waiting 12 months; some have been waiting four years. Patients have to wear this device before they can see the cardiologist. For urgent patients needing a monitor in CUH, the wait is up to four months. These are patients who are deemed to be urgent. The cost of this monitor is just €2,500. There is much technology, devices and equipment in the health sector that costs hundreds of thousands of euro. This is a very simple, relatively cheap device in the general scheme of things within the health sector.
Yet, we are not seeing the investment needed to ensure that the people involved can be properly monitored, get to see their cardiologists and move through the system.

There are so many blockages in the system. It is not just about staffing. So much of the conversation in this regard revolves around staffing, and rightly so, and beds. The conversation also needs to be about equipment and devices. We are not talking about CT scanners, MRIs or PET scanners in this instance; we are talking about a device that costs €2,500. In the context of a consultant seeing a patient, however, the latter could be waiting four years before they are monitored. It is a reflection of how broken parts of our health system are that we are not even getting the basics right. Ultimately, we need to make sure that we have a much more comprehensive and systematic attitude towards the collection of data in the health service. That is why the Labour Party is happy to support the Bill.

The NTPF is charged with a number of responsibilities, one of which is oversight of waiting lists in hospitals. There is a real issue now about where responsibility lies in terms of monitoring how people are allocated onto the in-service or outsourced service provision. Like Deputy Rice, I am less than 12 months in this brief as my party's spokesperson on health. In the context of all the revelations we have seen this year, one of the things which strikes me is that there is not a clear sense of responsibility as to who takes ownership of the transfer of people from waiting lists to the NTPF. The latter makes certain claims. Hospitals in certain areas have taken responsibility themselves, with varying degrees of consistency. We need to get the right level of transparency when it comes to the NTPF. So much money has been put into the fund. We do not want such reliance on the NTPF, but it has become a necessary evil that we have to outsource because there is no other option following a decade of underinvestment in the health service. A key part of the legislation before us relates to ensuring that there is greater transparency in the context of the NTPF. My party very much supports the Bill.

role.name: Minister of State at the Department of Health

speeches.speakerLabel: Minister of State at the Department of Health (Deputy Kieran O'Donnell)
paragraphs: I thank Deputies Cullinane and Ward for tabling this Bill and facilitating a discussion regarding the length of time people are waiting to access care in our health service. As stated previously, I am taking the debate on behalf of the Minister for Health, Jennifer Carroll MacNeill. I thank all the Deputies who contributed to the debate.

As already stated, while recognising the worthwhile intentions and aims of the Deputies in tabling this Bill, the Government is opposing it on the basis that the proposed measures are not necessary in light of the effectiveness of the current arrangements and structures that are already in place. There are rigorous and effective structures and processes in place for setting priorities and targets for delivery of health and social care services. These include the letter of determination, the national service plan and performance oversight within the HSE and between the HSE and the Department, including the waiting list action plan. In terms of the proposed measures to expand upon waiting list reporting set out in the Bill, significant work is already under way to improve and build upon the information available at present. However, the current limitations in relation to the availability of waiting lists to deliver the specific enhancements set out in the Bill would prevent the proposal from being implemented and would thereby undermine the intentional impact of the legislative change being proposed.

With regard to the proposal that the NTPF be made accountable to a committee of the Houses of the Oireachtas, I set out the thorough and extensive measures for oversight and governance of the fund that are in place between the Department and that organisation. In addition, the NTPF is required to appear before the public accounts committee, as specified in the legislation under which it was established. The NTPF has demonstrated willingness to engage with the Oireachtas upon request, including on a number of occasions this year. Obviously, at meetings of the public accounts committee, its representatives are questioned by Deputies on the basis of work done by the Comptroller and Auditor General.

As already outlined, the Government is satisfied the structures already in place are appropriate to ensure effective priorities and target setting as well as the live and extensive reporting of waiting list information. In addition, access to accurate data about patients waiting for service across the system is recognised as being crucial to how we can facilitate access to those services. However, it is important to remember that these are only aspects of the solution to address the key issue of the length of time people are waiting for treatment. The improvements achieved in terms of acute hospital waiting lists and waiting times are being driven by specific actions aimed at increasing capacity and embedding reform by means of the waiting list action plan approach. Examples of this include the ongoing establishment of the surgical hubs around the country and the further roll-out of modernised care pathways.

Embedding reform actions in our system will ensure the most efficient use of available resources in a patient-centred way, including initiative seeking to optimise the patient pathway from referral to discharge. The implementation and progression of the multi-annual action plan approach is not happening in isolation. The longer term reform of scheduled care and reduction in waiting times is interconnected with and influenced by a number of developments across the health service. This includes the continued focus on productivity and efficiency improvements and the shift of more care into community settings and alternative care pathways. These interdependencies underline the complexity of the system of the system and how an integrated and holistic approach is needed to ensure waiting times are improved across the health service to ensure people have access to the care they need when they need it.

If I was in government and was handed a script like the one the Minister of State was expected to deliver this evening - I assume by officials in the Department, but I do not know who crafted the speech - I hope that I would say, "No thank you, I am not going to read that out." It was embarrassing in the context of the reasons given for opposing this Bill. It is embarrassing for one simple reason, namely it is what the Minister of State and the Government signed up to. It is what we all signed up to when we agreed Sláintecare. An Teachta Rice is right. It is alarming that the Government is clearly stating that it is walking away from a commitment given to put in place statutory waiting list targets and maximum waiting list times.

The Minister of State is mixing up policy and policy targets, on the one hand, and statutory targets, on the other. That is the difference between what this Bill seeks to do and what he outlined. What we see routinely from this Government are HSE service plans. These are produced every year but are not worth the paper they are written on because the HSE does not have the capacity to meet any of the targets. Almost every target that is set is broken. The Minister of State cited all of the targets set out even in the most recent waiting list plan to reduce wait times in some areas by 50%. Nobody out there, not even the people who wrote the script for him, believe that is going to happen. All we have are these published fantasy targets. It is a case of "We will see what is going to happen, but we are not going to do anything and do not really care." That is what I hear from Government.

Before I get into some of the process issues behind the Bill and the reasons I think the explanations the Minister of State gave are utter nonsense, I highlight the fact that I am also of the view that we will not reduce waiting lists until we put capacity into the system. We have to build the four elective hospitals. We have to deliver on the hospital beds. We have to deliver on the diagnostic capacity. We have to upgrade equipment. We need new equipment in some hospitals, and we need staff. We need to train more healthcare professionals to fill the gaps where there are staff shortages. All of those are obvious ingredients when it comes to reducing waiting lists and providing faster care.

In the context of Sláintecare, it is understood that process is important. Setting targets is also important, however. I do not believe we will ever solve the problem in emergency departments and have a situation where people will not be left on trolleys if we do not adopt a zero-tolerance approach. That is precisely what happened in Waterford, where the hospital manager at the time said that one person on a hospital trolley was one too many and adopted a zero-tolerance approach as a result. He did not believe change would happen overnight, or in a week or a month.

However, if we set it as a target, the entire system - the staff, consultants, nurses, healthcare assistants, radiographers and everybody working in hospitals and in other parts of the healthcare system which are crucial in the context of reducing crises in emergency departments and identifying what the capacity needs are - will be forced to get us to a point where we do not have patients on trolleys. That is precisely what happened and it would not have happened if a zero-tolerance approach had not been taken.

It is the same with the maximum wait time targets. The reason Sláintecare set those targets was that it was believed, on the advice of the Department, the HSE and all the experts who came before the special Oireachtas committee that looked at Sláintecare, it was possible to do it. The purpose of setting a maximum wait time was to force the system to put the capacity in to meeting that objective. The Government is now walking away from that. The Minister of State shook his head earlier when he indicated it was not but clearly it is. The reason he gave for opposing this Bill was that the Government did not have to accept this because it was doing it anyway. It is not doing it. It does not have statutory targets. I do not know if the Minister of State could point to me where on the Statute Book the Government has ever legislated for the Sláintecare targets. I know it has not done so.

Coming then to the community waiting lists, I find the Government's response on those even worse, and breathtaking in many ways. It is an acceptance of utter failure by the Government. It is really saying it cannot publish the community waiting list times through the NTPF, in the same way as the acute hospitals, because we are not up to that standard yet. What an appalling response and appalling situation for us to find ourselves in. We have children and adults on those waiting lists waiting for access to dentists, dietitians, speech and language therapists and all the other community waiting lists. We get those responses back through parliamentary questions. They may not be perfect, and I made that point earlier, but at least we get numbers. It is possible for Government to publish those waiting list times. If they are imperfect and need to be improved or brought up to a standard similar to those for the acute hospitals, that can happen over time and evolve. However, simply to say we are not doing it because we do not believe we can do it to the same standard as acute hospital waiting lists is not a satisfactory response. We have an entitlement to the highest levels of transparency. I imagine it frustrates patients that we spend tens of billions every year on health and yet there is basic information we cannot collate or publish.

I will finish how I started. If I was in the Minister of State's shoes, I would have handed the speech back and said, "No thanks, I am not going to read that out" because it essentially tells the public the Government is again walking away from one of the key proposals and action points it had in accepting Sláintecare. That is regrettable. My party remains committed to Sláintecare and to the highest levels of transparency in the health service for waiting lists. We also remain committed to people getting timely, fast and rapid access to care, as best we can. This will not happen overnight and there is a lot to be done to get to a point where we can reach those targets. Unless we take targets seriously, however, which the Government is not doing based on the Minister of State's speech, and use those targets to mobilise and marshal the resources of the health service to meet them, patients will continue to wait. I gave the examples of patients waiting for cataract, hip and hernia operations, which are standard day-case procedures in most cases, but there are others, including cancer care, cardiac care and so on.
I am disappointed the Minister of State is not accepting this Bill. I will take this up with the Minister for Health.

role.name: An Cathaoirleach Gníomhach

paragraphs: In accordance with Standing Order 85(2), the division is postponed until the weekly division time next week.

sections.title: Engagement with An Taoiseach

paragraphs: I remind all those in attendance to ensure their mobile phones are switched off or on silent mode. Apologies have been received from Deputies Callaghan, Keogh, O'Donoghue, Kelly, Lawlor and O'Connor. In their place, I welcome the Leas-Chathaoirligh, Deputies Dempsey, Ó Cearúil and Brennan and Senator Ní Chuilinn, who are representing their committees. I also welcome the Taoiseach, who will engage with the Working Group of Committee Cathaoirligh. We are delighted to have him here today. He is accompanied by officials from the Department of the Taoiseach, Mr. Dermot Woods, assistant principal, and Mr. Denis Breen, principal officer.

The purpose of today's meeting, in accordance with Standing Orders 130 and 118, is to discuss matters of public policy, particularly those raised through our respective committees. As the Taoiseach knows, committees allow TDs and Senators to engage meaningfully and directly with Departments, public bodies, relevant stakeholders and the wider public. Today's meeting allows us as Cathaoirligh a chance to discuss the committees' work with the Taoiseach. I trust the meeting will be mutually beneficial.
On that note, we will proceed directly to the substantive part of the meeting. I ask the Taoiseach to make his opening statement.

role.name: Minister for Defence.

paragraphs: Gabhaim buíochas leis an gcoiste as ucht an chuiridh a bheith anseo inniu. Tá súil agam go mbeidh an cruinniú seo úsáideach dúinn go léir. Deis atá ann dom freisin ball an choiste a chur ar an eolas faoi cad atá ar siúl ag an Rialtas agus faoi roinnt de na polasaithe atá faoi chaibidil againn. I thank the Cathaoirleach for the invitation to be here today. At the outset, I acknowledge the importance of our committee system. Committees play a valuable role in the parliamentary process, involving detailed scrutiny of legislation, spending and policies, and engaging with members of the public, stakeholders and officials. I thank the Cathaoirligh and Leas-Chathaoirligh for their contribution to this collective effort. I am keen to hear how their work is progressing and to discuss issues of common interest.
I have a few brief introductory remarks to update members on the work of the Government. It does not cover all of the issues but it gives a snapshot of some of the issues we have been dealing with.

I was very glad to welcome President Zelenskyy and the First Lady of Ukraine last week. We all had the honour of hearing his words in person at the joint sitting. Ireland's solidarity with Ukraine is unchanged. I assured the President of Ireland's continuing support. The Government announced an additional €100 million in non-lethal military support, as well as €25 million for Ukraine's energy supplies to help to counter Russia's ongoing attacks on their vital infrastructure.

In the changed European security environment, Ireland clearly needs to invest more in our security and defence capabilities, including against the growing cyber and hybrid threats. Indeed, there is a shared assessment that Europe needs to do more. It is important that Ireland is an active participant in the process while respecting our traditional policy of military neutrality. In the 2026 budget, the Government provided a record €1.5 billion allocation in defence funding and a record €1.7 billion in defence capital investment as part of our revised national development plan. Very significant work has been and is taking place under the Commission on the Defence Forces to improve our military capability: the acquisition of primary radar and subsea sonar capability; additional air assets; counter drone capabilities; and continued work to tackle recruitment and retention issues. In the modern security environment, no state can counter shared challenges alone. We must and will continue to work with partners in protecting our national interests and our shared European interests. That is absolutely key.

President Zelenskyy thanked Ireland for providing homes and protection to Ukrainians when they needed it most and looked forward to the day when Ukrainians can welcome all their friends to their own country in peace. Ireland will always be a place to offer protection to those fleeing war and persecution and will always adopt a firm but fair approach to migration, which is an essential part of maintaining our successful economy. Ireland fully supports the priority afforded to the EU migration agenda. Europe must collectively address the shared challenges of unplanned migration and operate a predictable and flexible system, characterised by responsibility and solidarity, for the reception and management of protection applications. The EU migration and asylum pact represents a necessary improvement on the current protection system and we propose to modernise and strengthen our legislative and policy framework for both international protection and naturalisation. These changes will ensure closer alignment with established practice in other EU member states and also take account of developments in the United Kingdom.

I met with Prime Minister Starmer last week at the British-Irish Council summit in Wales and we noted the progress made on implementing the commitments in the UK-Ireland 2030 programme of strategic co-operation. We look forward to the second UK-Ireland summit, which Ireland will host in spring next year. The publication on 19 September of a joint framework addressing the legacy of the Troubles represents a clear break with the 2023 UK legacy Act and shows a return to partnership by the two Governments on Northern Ireland, working together as co-guarantors of the Good Friday Agreement. We also referenced the publication this week of the entire Kenova report. I commend the authors of that report, which reveals a very sordid situation in Northern Ireland for over 25 years in terms of the use of agents in collusion but also in terms of appalling campaigns of terror against communities in Northern Ireland by paramilitaries. We also got a summary of the Denton report. I regret that the full report is not available. I look forward to the Dáil debating both reports in the new year.

Through the expanded and strengthened shared island initiative, backed by our commitment of €2 billion to the shared island fund out to 2035, the Government is continuing to work to foster reconciliation, mutual respect and growth. About €500 million of that has now been allocated to a range of projects and programmes. There is the dialogue strand and the research strand. The objective is to bring co-operation and relationships across the island of Ireland to a new level. Last month, the Government announced allocations of over €50 million from the shared island fund for ten new projects that are now being taken forward by Ministers.

The delivery of essential infrastructure is a key driver in ensuring our economy's competitiveness and resilience. In the past five years, more than €65 billion has been invested in capital infrastructure projects. Persistent and accelerated progress in delivery across areas such as housing, healthcare, energy, water and wastewater, innovation, and addressing climate change are crucial in maintaining and strengthening our prosperity.

The Government's new accelerating infrastructure action plan will help drive the efficient delivery of infrastructure across Ireland by addressing critical barriers to infrastructure development. We are moving at pace to reform our planning system.

This includes enabling local authorities to zone sufficient land for residential development to support the step-up required in delivery. Last month, the Government published a new housing plan, which aims to deliver 300,000 new homes by the end of 2030. The new plan, informed by the work of the Housing Commission, will empower the State, partners and the private sector to play a critical part in delivery. It is underpinned by the largest ever capital investment in the history of the State, with €275 billion in infrastructure over ten years through the revised national development plan.

We will continue to invest in our economy and our people and the services they need. Budget 2026 demonstrates our strong commitment to plan for and secure Ireland's future, while preserving the jobs, stability and prosperity of today. We are fully aware of the competitiveness challenges we face. We are working hard to ensure Ireland remains a trusted, stable and attractive location for businesses in a rapidly changing world. The recent Government action plan on competitiveness and productivity provides a concrete policy to our economic vision, focusing on elements within our domestic sphere of influence.

As a small global economy, Ireland has greatly benefited from international trade and the European Union Single Market as well as cultivating and nurturing strong international relationships. With our market diversification action plan, published in August, we aim to expand these relationships and identify new market opportunities by utilising our membership of the Single Market, eliminating trade barriers and addressing sector-specific needs.

At the recent meeting of COP30, Ireland stood firmly with the European Union in pursuing ambitious new national contributions aligned with keeping global warming below 1.5°C, while championing adaptation and supporting the world's most vulnerable nations. As a country and as a Government, we are serious about meeting our responsibilities in the fight against climate change. The latest Environmental Protection Agency figures show three consecutive years of emissions reductions. Our emissions are now at their lowest level in 35 years despite very significant population and economic growth over that period. However, progress is not fast enough. We simply need to do more, and we have to do it more quickly. That, obviously, relates to the energy issue.

Ireland has faced real pressures on energy costs but the picture is improving. Renewables are now steadily reducing the cost of electricity. The Government is investing at a record scale to help families cut bills for good. Budget 2026 provides €558 million for energy upgrades and solar supports. If we maintain that, it will be the highest ever. That is a very tangible and effective way of reducing household bills eventually for a lot of houses. We have to keep at that, making homes warmer, healthier and cheaper to heat.

I have just come from a meeting of the climate investment clearing house, which I established in this Government. The offshore wind agenda is absolutely critical. The clearing house brings regulators, industry and Departments together to identify the barriers and potential obstacles because it offshore wind is an economic imperative and opportunity on so many fronts. It is essential for energy security and to meet our climate goals. We simply have to deliver the offshore wind agenda. We are working extremely hard to do that. In parallel with that, we have to move very fast to create a strategic emergency gas reserve. I know there have been some critics of that, but that is fundamentally a security imperative. We are looking at how we can accelerate that in the time ahead.

Budget 2026, the first of five budgets for this Government, reflects our level of ambition and commitment. It is the first step on the journey the Government will take to positively impact disabled people's lives and give them and their families support where they need it most. It has a strong focus on disability, including a record €3.8 billion allocation toward specialist disability services; a significant social protection package with increases to core rates and changes to income disregards for carers; a €3 billion investment in special education and the return of therapists to schools, that is, a school therapy service, which is working well; and a health schedule. The newly established disability unit in my Department will bring a renewed focus, urgency and weight to disability issues. In particular, the unit will look to further drive innovation and get things done, give momentum to policy implementation, improve delivery of services, troubleshoot, as appropriate, and encourage strategic thought on future challenges.

In September, the Government announced its new ambitious target to reduce consistent child poverty to 3% by the end of 2030. In the budget, important milestones were achieved. It is the first year of a multi-year programme to achieve our target. We announced a significant increase in targeted income supports for low-income families as well as increased funding for targeted measures to support access and participation in early learning and school-age childcare through the new DEIS plus scheme and the roll-out of the equal start programme.

In under seven months, on 1 July 2026, Ireland will take on the Presidency of the Council of the European Union for the eighth time. I met President Costa on Tuesday to go through the agenda and the critical items around competitiveness, values and the core issues, such as the multi-annual financial framework that we will be expected to bring to a conclusion during our Presidency, which will be critical for so many sectors of European issues but also Irish interests. We are very determined to resource and deliver a successful Presidency as it is an important opportunity for Ireland to lead the European Union's agenda and to shape the future.

Enlargement will also feature during our Presidency. We are anxious to see real concrete progress on enlargement. Work is continuing across the Government to develop our priorities policy programme, taking account of the EU strategic agenda for 2024-2029 and the legislative programme proposed by the European Commission.
I look forward to hearing members' views on these and any other matters they wish to raise. Go raibh maith agaibh.
I thank the Taoiseach for his opening statement and the broad range of issues he covered.

Before we move on to the next part of the meeting, I remind members of the long-standing parliamentary practice to the effect they should not comment on, criticise or make charges against a person outside the Houses or an official either by name or in such a way as to make him or her identifiable.

I will give a recap of the procedures we have agreed. We will take questions from Cathaoirligh in groups of three. Cathaoirligh will be called upon in order of their appointment under the D’Hondt system. We will then hear from the Cathaoirligh of the non-D’Hondt committees. A time limit of two minutes per Cathaoirleach will apply. That is the time available because there are a lot of Members here and the Taoiseach has to leave at 12.50 p.m. at the latest. In the event that somebody is not present, I will move on to the next person on the list and if those who are absent come in, we will try to accommodate them later. Deputy Neville, Leas-Chathaoirleach of my committee, is in the first group of Cathaoirligh. He will be followed by Deputy Carrigy, Cathaoirleach of the Joint Committee on Housing, Local Government and Heritage, and Deputy Farrell, Cathaoirleach of the Joint Committee on Finance, Public Expenditure, Public Service Reform and Digitalisation, and Taoiseach. They have two minutes each in that sequence.

I thank the Taoiseach very much for coming this morning. I am the Leas-Chathaoirleach of the Committee on Infrastructure and National Development Plan Delivery, a new committee that is dealing with probably the single biggest challenge this Government faces. Also, because we do not necessarily deal with legislation, we are trying to figure out exactly where the committee works well and works best. We will see that over time.

We have had a number of speakers and groups appear before the committee. Uisce Éireann highlighted that the greater Dublin drainage system is a key issue. Will the Government provide all possible supports to ensure the project is completed in a timely manner?

Officials from the Department of Transport came in, including the Secretary General. The Luas failed yesterday and it is still not working. We were told last week that the M50 is full to capacity. How is it planned to make Dublin even stronger in that area? A couple of weeks ago, DART+ South West was on the agenda. It is now off the agenda. What we need is to have continuity and plans in place, which is not necessarily the case. We would like to see that done given the situation we are in and the level of capital investment that seems to be in place.

On housing, we had large developers in. One of the issues they raised was the lack of zoning in large rural towns such as Clonmel and Tullamore. That is on the rural side. There is also the cost associated with construction and the potential for profit in the likes of Longford and Mullingar. There is a need for infrastructure in the commuter areas. We also need to tackle the electricity side of things, for example, as regards supply, the grid and judicial reviews. Then there is the issue of multi-annual funding for large-scale projects.
I thank the Deputy. I move to Deputy Carrigy.
I thank the Taoiseach.

As a committee, we welcome the recent announcement of the housing plan, the accelerated infrastructure task force report and the aim to deliver 300,000 homes in Ireland by 2030. The reality is that is going to be a challenge due to numerous issues such as planning or the issue of judicial reviews. We currently have judicial reviews in place with regard to the proposed changes to planning regulations for apartments to try and unlock the 30,000 planning permissions for apartments which have not yet been utilised. There are other issues, such as the delay in opening up lands on the way to the airport for the metro north. The Shannon to Dublin water infrastructure project has been held up and has not been delivered. When we had Irish Water before the committee, its representatives told us that on certain days recently it did not produce enough water to supply the current number of homes in Dublin. How are we going to meet our targets to supply new homes if that infrastructure is not put in place? Is it time to do what we did when it came to the bypass for Adare? We put in significant investment to make sure the infrastructure is going to be there in time for the Ryder Cup. We need to bypass some of the legal loopholes that are holding us up when it comes to putting in the infrastructure we need to hit our targets.

There are a number of Bills, such as the apartment and duplex defects remediation Bill and the residential tenancies Bill, on which we are carrying out pre-legislative scrutiny and putting in a considerable amount of work. I ask that those recommendations be taken on board and that we do not leave any of the apartment owners behind or out of pocket. We have to make sure we give them the full support they deserve.

I will update the Taoiseach on some of the work done by the Joint Committee on Finance, Public Expenditure, Public Service Reform and Digitalisation, and Taoiseach. In the summer months, we focused on the facilitation of Israeli bonds by the Central Bank and published a report to that effect in early August in anticipation of the review. We have also subsequently dealt with the Central Bank in relation to that.

We also focused on the Security Action for Europe, SAFE, legislation and regulation going through the EU in terms of the €800 billion loans. We are hoping to publish that report, to be entitled Prioritisation of Defence Spending in the EU, next week. We have also worked through numerous pieces of legislation. We obviously had the Finance Bill 2025. Each year, the finance Bill is the largest Bill that goes through the Dáil every year and it goes through our committee.

We will also be looking at the right to be forgotten Bill as soon as it is ready. We hoped to have it before Christmas, but I would say it will be set for after Christmas, at this stage. We have also looked at digital banks. We had the Central Bank and the Banking and Payments Federation Ireland in to discuss the issue of online safety with online banking, digital banks and other banks to try to create awareness in relation to it. Digital banks will also be attending in January to discuss this issue.

Our committee is the committee the Taoiseach comes before. The Revised Estimates will have to be done before the end of February. We look forward to having the Taoiseach in to discuss his own Votes, Votes 1 to 6. How many times does the Taoiseach expect to come before our committee next year? Can we work together collaboratively to ensure he can come in when it is needed? Can we ensure we do the planning at an early stage to make sure it is workable for everybody?
The Taoiseach has four minutes.

role.name: Minister for Defence.

paragraphs: In response to Deputy Neville, mediation is taking place on the Dublin drainage system. The bottom line is that all supports are being given from an investment perspective. Water, grid, public transport and road transport are absolutely essential, in my view. We have huge population growth. Our infrastructure is historically behind, but those are the imperatives. All possible supports will be given. We are looking at and going to produce a critical infrastructure Bill to deal with issues like the Dublin drainage scheme. It is absolutely critical for the people of Dublin to have water.

DART+ South West is not off the agenda. It is on the agenda. I have discussed it with the Minister for public expenditure and the Minister, Deputy Darragh O'Brien. We are conscious of its importance. Deputy Shane Moynihan has been very vibrant in terms of advocating on this, as have others. I want to make it clear that it is not off the agenda. We understand that significant zoning is part and parcel of that. The council needs to go ahead and do the zoning given the housing needs in the area.

In terms of rural towns infrastructure, Uisce Éireann is now working with developers in terms of smaller housing projects in rural areas. The provision of wastewater treatment plants will be developer led to enable housing projects to get off the ground. Uisce Éireann will specify the standards and oversee it afterwards. That will unblock a lot of developments.
We are investing in the Luas and public transport under the national development plan.

On the issue of judicial reviews, which Deputy Carrigy also raised, we have gone out to public consultation on a new cost regime for judicial reviews, which will be far more realistic and sensible in terms of the State's exposure, but also in terms of having a framework that makes sense. A public consultation on the locus standi provisions in the planning Act in respect of judicial review has also been commenced. The Minister for justice will bring forward further reforms in respect of judicial reviews, whereby the balance lies in the public interest as opposed to an individual's interest.

Deputy Carrigy raised similar issues in terms of housing and judicial reviews. I welcome that there is increased mediation taking place in respect of some of these issues. They might unblock some of the challenges. We have substantially resourced An Coimisiún Pleanála. Timelines are improving in terms of outcomes within the statutory time guidelines. The Shannon to Dublin water programme is absolutely essential for the midlands and for the east coast. There are no alternatives in terms of sufficiency of water supply into the future. Again, that is a critical piece of infrastructure. One of the challenges facing us as an Oireachtas is that all Members will come under pressure in their constituencies in respect of some items that have been identified nationally from a macro perspective as essential for the country. Whether Members are in government or in opposition, the reconciliation of all of that is proving challenging on the energy, infrastructure and economic fronts. The bypass of Adare for the Ryder Cup is a good example, but, of course, it had gone through all the planning processes. During Brexit, significant infrastructural work had to be carried out on the ports, and we got it done. Dublin Port, in particular, had to be done quickly. People did what was necessary to enable that to happen. There was an emergency situation-----
The Taoiseach's four minutes is up. Will he quickly respond to the issues raised by Deputy Farrell?

role.name: Minister for Defence.

paragraphs: I am sorry. Was it four minutes? First, I appreciate the workload of the committee. Deputy Farrell outlined all its reports. I look forward to the report on the SAFE legislation. It is important. The finance Bill is the largest one. I did the Estimates. I did not do the Supplementary Estimates as I was not in a position to get there.
As a precedent, will the Taoiseach outline the dates for next year?

role.name: Minister for Defence.

paragraphs: I will outline them. I will go by precedent, but I will try to be facilitative and co-operative as well. I think there was a €3 million Supplementary Estimate for my Department, which I was not in a position to do. We did not think it was the case that previously, a Taoiseach would have turned up for a very small Supplementary Estimate. We will work with the committee in terms of dates and so on.

I will move on to the next group of Chairs, namely, Deputy Devlin, who deals with the committee on the Good Friday Agreement, Deputy Barry Ward, who deals with the Committee on European Affairs - Deputy Carthy is not here and we will come back to him - and then we will move on to Deputy Lahart, Chair of the foreign affairs and trade committee, as part of this group of three.

I thank the Taoiseach for his opening remarks and his mention of the North-South update. The theme of health has featured heavily in our committee since its establishment in May. An appearance yesterday by the Northern Ireland Minister of Health, Mr. Mike Nesbitt MLA, proved very fruitful and there was good, strong engagement. We also had discussions in relation to North-South co-operation and the need to prioritise high-potential projects in the civic engagement and public health spaces, in particular. In health, we focused mainly on cancer care and paediatric cardiology.

The committee also had a very positive engagement on the shared island theme with the Taoiseach's Department in September, which he referred to in his opening remarks. The committee heard of its benefits from a range of stakeholders. In fairness, in nearly every engagement the committee has had, people have referenced potential funding from the shared island initiative.

Our committee alone could spend that €2 billion but it has proved exceptionally beneficial for various groups in research and particularly on the infrastructure piece. We are exploring the possibility an all-island league for soccer, both men and women, and it is hoped that will be looked upon favourably if an application comes in to the shared island initiative. Also the committee has received significant support from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, especially on civic engagement, and in relation to the developments on legacy. Members of the Good Friday Agreement committee met the Northern Ireland Affairs committee on 1 December. This was an important opportunity to discuss latter's report on legacy. Members have also taken the opportunity to engage with the British-Irish Parliamentary Association and the North-South Inter-Parliamentary Association. In January, the committee hopes to visit Belfast and engage on regular visits to groups in other parts of Northern Ireland as well as visiting London under strand 3 of the Good Friday Agreement committee.

Gabhaim buíochas leis an Taoiseach as a bheith linn. Glacamid i dtús báire leis an méid a duirt sé faoi tábhacht choistí an Oireachtas. As important as the committees are in the pre-legisaltive scrutiny process, there have been a number of instances in the last number of years where committees have made specific recommendations on heads of Bills that have subsequently been completely ignored by the Departments. As a result, the legislation that has come before the Oireachtas has completely discounted what has been recommended by the committee. I do not know whether the Taoiseach feels he can comment on that. If the committees and the pre-legislative scrutiny are important, to what extent are Ministers and Departments bound to consider what they say and actually implement that in the legislation that goes before the Oireachtas?

In relation to my own committee on European affairs, obviously we are focusing in particular on the Presidency that is coming up next year. Will the Taoiseach give us an update on the preparations for the themes and the priorities of the Irish Presidency and the resourcing and logistical preparations, including the security implications of the Presidency?

Another very important issue in our work programme is the EU enlargement agenda, which we feel very strongly is moving too slowly. It is now more than a decade since we last had an accession, in 2013. Accession is good for all of us, particularly for the smaller members, like Ireland. We feel there is a danger that if there is no feeling of progress, the anti-EU elements within the accession countries are given a stick with which to beat those who are pro-Europe. There is a real opportunity for Ireland in the course of the Presidency to advance the enlargement agenda. We have asked the EU Commissioner for European Enlargement, Marta Kos, to come to us to speak to us about that as well.

In relation to the economic side, obviously the multi-annual financial framework will be a big focus over the coming year. The EU Commissioner for Budget, Anti-Fraud and Public Administration, Piotr Serafin, is due to be with us in the new year as well. There is a real opportunity for Ireland to advance, and perhaps the Taoiseach would comment on Ireland's priorities in relation to the MFF negotiations during our Presidency.

Cuirim fíorchinn fáilte roimh an Taoiseach anseo inniu. I want to update him on some of work we have done across the four pillars of the Committee on Foreign Affairs and Trade, namely, Anglo-Irish and North American; international, which is everything from Sudan to Ukraine and in between; development aid and development assistance; and the trade piece. The committee has just returned from Canada and the Taoiseach has been there himself on a trade visit, as has the Minister, Deputy Burke. Canada is very much open for business with exciting opportunities there. The Taoiseach's visit went down particularly well there and we are privileged to have a really dynamic ambassador on the ground there also and some very interesting initiatives are coming up there.

In relation to a number of the issues that we covered, the impact of the loss of USAID in terms of the development agenda internationally has exercised the committee. We waived pre-legislative scrutiny on CETA, and I know that is before Government and will be coming back before the committee in January or February. We produced a report on the occupied territories Bill and made certain recommendations in relation to it. That is with Government. We had the EU Commissioner for Trade and Economic Security, Maroš Šefčovič, here. We were also dealing with the EU-Morocco trade piece.

In terms of the EU Presidency, some of the things that we would like the Taoiseach to bear in mind include the sustainability piece, the climate action piece - they are issues that are brought to us - and the development aid piece.

The final bit is in relation to the Middle East, where there is a fragile peace process, as the Taoiseach is more than aware. Ireland has some expertise in that peace space, from decommissioning to the drafting of complex peace agreements and achieving consensus. As a committee we think that is a space we would like to move into early in the new year. We would like the Taoiseach's response to that, especially in relation to Ireland reputation in that part of the world.

role.name: Minister for Defence.

paragraphs: I thank all the Deputies. To Deputy Devlin, first of all, the health area has been quite a significant arena for good North-South co-operation, as he mentioned, for paediatric cardiac surgery in particular. There is an all-Ireland approach to that, and this matters in terms of outcomes and quality of outcomes. The cancer care and cardiac care centres at Altnagelvin Area Hospital provide real opportunities for people in the Republic living within 90 minutes of the centre, which I visited some time ago.

The shared island initiative is proving to be very beneficial and effective, not just in the iconic projects around Narrow Water Bridge and the Ulster Canal but also very good tourism projects that are developing. When completed, these will make Carlingford and the Mourne Mountains area a real destination point. It will enhance the economy and the socialisation of people coming together and engaging. The economy will improve significantly in that region.

On the legacy, for the British Government and this Government, it has been a step change in the nature of the relationship, particularly in terms of the heads-up approach to the legislation and the framework. This is a significant improvement by any yardstick on the previous experience and on the previous legislation. I welcome what the committee is doing in its North-South Inter-Parliamentary Association engagement and its British-Irish Parliamentary Association engagement, which are extremely important.

I would be very interested in an all-Ireland soccer league or tournament because I think it is one sport that has potential for reconciliation and bringing people together again. Rugby has done this very well and has been very effective. It is an area that we certainly would be positive about.

Deputy Ward's points are an-thábachtach ar fad. The Executive is not bound by any recommendations. I can say that as a Minister I always accepted amendments to any legislation that were sensible and intelligent. Every Minister should have an open view and should accept amendments at all stages of the legislative process and should reflect on points that are made and should not offer knee-jerk negativity if good points are made. That is why committees are there, to see if there are agendas. It cuts both ways as there has to be a realistic assessment on the committee side as well as to what is possible. Sometimes things can be properly presented because they are good but it may not be legislatively possible, but it is to and fro. Yes, in short, we should be embracing the idea of amendments. I never brought a Bill through the House that did not change from the time it was initiated.

On the enlargement agenda, we are going to affirm competitiveness and the values of democracy that distinguish Europe. We would like to close all chapters on Montenegro and Ukraine. We think we need a concrete example of where enlargement can happen. It will fall on us to drive the Ukrainian membership agenda. Hungary has proved difficult up to now. The multi-annual financial framework will fall during our Presidency in terms of concluding parts of that.

The Common Agricultural Policy, CAP, will be key. It is nowhere near where it needs to be. It is 80% of what it was the last time. That is very problematic in terms of real money into farmers' pockets to sustain farming.

Horizon Europe is critical for the competitiveness in the future in Europe. We have to be very realistic about the size of the budget. In my view, it is not large enough to accommodate all the various interests. Defence will be part of the next multi-annual financial framework. I favour a GNI approach, which is transparent. We are net contributors.

On foreign affairs, I could not agree more with Deputy Lahart. The Canadian Prime Minister has made it very clear that he is pivoting to Europe strategically and Europe needs to engage. Canada is part of Security Action for Europe, SAFE, for example. We are looking forward to further engagement on the trade front with Canada and the ratification of CETA.
We appreciate the work the committee has done on the occupied territories Bill, which is under Government consideration.
I hear what the Deputy has to say about the Presidency and the importance of the sustainability piece, which will be a core part.
On the Middle East we need to pivot to considering what contribution we can make to the peace process. People are interested in the Irish experience of conflict resolution.

We are working with partners on that agenda already, determining how we can contribute given our experience. I would welcome the committee's engagement on that given our experience on this island. That is something we would like to return to the committee on.

The Taoiseach is welcome and I thank him for his engagement. We are doing a lot of good work on the Joint Committee on Education and Youth. I acknowledge the presence of our fantastic clerk, Tara, today with her team. They are doing great work. A huge body of work has been undertaken by the committee so far but I will home in on one area in my questioning.

Evidential research shows there have been exponential increases in anxiety, depression and other mental health issues among students, especially since the Covid pandemic. The education and youth committee had a very beneficial meeting on mental health supports in primary and post-primary schools with departmental officials, including some NEPS psychologists. Feedback we received from teachers, parents and students regarding the pilot counselling programme in primary schools has been very positive. The programme is unique in that the counsellors work with students in the school. Their work is complemented by the well-being education practitioners who work with individual students and educate all students about positive mental health through understanding and how to build resilience. It encourages a whole-school culture that supports well-being and negates bullying among the school community. Does the Taoiseach agree there is merit to rolling out the programme nationwide to all primary and post-primary schools? Post-primary students need even greater mental health supports. The current Neart programme at second level is a positive step but is being delivered virtually in classrooms. This is not ideal and it cannot offer the breadth and depth of supports needed by students.

Does the Taoiseach agree the absence of formal links between schools and CAMHS is a serious problem and a barrier to providing students with holistic mental health support? Will he consider establishing these links on a pilot basis so principals and teachers can work with CAMHS to help students and parents in need in a more structured way?

The public is outraged by the countless recent examples of wasteful spending of taxpayers' money, whether on financial scandals within RTÉ, runaway ICT costs, security huts or bike shelters, all of which have been examined by the Committee of Public Accounts. The list goes on and on. These individual incidents have highlighted a general need to strengthen how the State oversees the spending of public funds. Our statutory framework for the Comptroller and Auditor General is outdated and inhibits the ability of the public accounts committee to play its role as watchdog on public expenditure. The 2020 independent peer review made it clear that limits on the C and AG's powers and independence must be removed. We need to operate according to a genuine follow-the-money principle, removing the 50% threshold that blocks inspections of many Government-funded bodies by the C and AG and the public accounts committee. All bodies in receipt of public funds, including local authorities and commercial semi-State entities, should fall under the remit of the C and AG. The Committee of Public Accounts must also have an expanded and clearer role and be empowered to act quickly on C and AG findings, conduct follow-up inquiries and hold any publicly funded body to account. Oversight should be proactive and not reactive.

I have three questions. First, will the Government commit to the suite of reforms recommended in the 2020 independent peer review for the C and AG? Second, will it honour its commitment to bring RTÉ under the remit of the C and AG? Third, will it commit to expanding the remit of the C and AG and the public accounts committee to enable oversight of all publicly funded bodies?

As Chair of the Committee on Transport, I will focus on road safety. Notwithstanding the ambition in our road safety strategy to reduce road deaths and serious injuries by 50% by 2030, the reality on the ground is sadly different, with 170 precious lives lost on our roads so far this year. We have lost 30 precious lives linked to motorcycle accidents, the highest level in 20 years. You have to go back to 2007 to see similar numbers. We do not have an NCT-type test for motorcycles and this is something the committee will be looking at.

I have three asks. First is that the Taoiseach engage with the Minister and the Garda Commissioner on numbers in our road policing units. The former Commissioner, Drew Harris, appeared before the committee in May 2024 and committed to 150 additional gardaí in our road policing units by the end of this year. Unfortunately, Assistant Commissioner Gunne confirmed in October that only 68 of these positions have been filled, leaving the number 82 short of 150. Bear in mind that current numbers in our road policing units stand at 693 while in 2009, they stood at 1,000.

My second ask is for the prioritisation in 2026 of the passage and commencement of the national vehicle and driver file Bill 2025. This enables the sharing of data between the RSA, An Garda Síochána and local authorities.

Finally, there is something the Taoiseach might raise again with the Minister and the Commissioner. It may surprise him to know that over the past three years 23,000 individuals have failed to surrender their licence after disqualification. Only 4% presented their licence in the courts. The RSA has a system whereby you send your licence after you are disqualified to a PO box in Cork and only 6% did this.
As transport Chair, I acknowledge the work of the road safety advocacy group, PARC, which the committee works closely with.

role.name: Minister for Defence.

paragraphs: First was Deputy Crowe. I thank him for his remarks. There is real concern, and we are picking this up from talking to teachers, about positive mental health, mental well-being, anxiety and depression issues among children and young people. In any schools I visit, there is a strong focus on the various programmes to create a culture of well-being, mutual respect and people looking out for one another. I would be in favour of the pilot counselling programme being rolled out nationally. The well-being programme is effective and impactful. I will talk to the Minister on the plans for the Neart programme.

The Deputy also raised the interesting issue of linkages between schools and CAMHS. There would be clinical issues there. There is the GP issue in terms of primary care being the referral mode but an exchange between the two would be useful. NEPS certainly has a role. I established that body when I was Minister for Education. The idea was to introduce psychology to schooling in a positive, proactive way, not a reactive way, and to spot things much earlier in the life journey of a child through learning. It is particularly important to always nurture self-esteem and self-respect in the child. These are good programmes which we need to resource more into the future.

I could not agree more with Deputy Brady that we need to be very strong on spending, value for money and making sure we do not have overruns. Many of our projects do not overrun. Many are on time. Many Iarnród Éireann projects have been very effective. We need to, collectively and honestly as an Oireachtas, examine ourselves. One of the huge expenditure areas for the past two decades is the methodology we use for inquiries. They never end on time, in terms of the prescribed timelines that people allocate. We are talking about millions and millions. Is that the most effective way to allocate resources or to get the answers that undoubtedly are needed?

We never question ourselves in relation to that. Whether in government or in opposition, people will instinctively call for a public inquiry on most issues, notwithstanding the length of time it will take and the costs involved. I fully accept the need in government and across the systems for ensuring value for money but do we as individual representatives in the Oireachtas, every single time we call for this, that or the other actually it check out? The whole idea of the Parliamentary Budget Office was to assist Deputies in costing but it has become different. To me, its remit has broadened. The original concept in Dáil reform in 2016 was that it would cost proposals and give a greater degree of realism in terms of legislation that is brought before the House asking for something, pushing an agenda or so on. There are costs behind everything we do. I welcome the focus on this but I would broaden it to look at ourselves in terms of what we all want, promote and so on, for a bit of discipline.

I agree that RTÉ will come under the remit. We will look positively on the suite of reforms but I reserve the right to examine it in greater detail. There are commitments to expand the remit. We have to be careful of the degree. Are we going to bring in every sports club? We need to think through all of this. Sometimes, we go overboard. Some days, we have committees in here talking about overregulation and the next week the committees will want more regulation. We had the issue with Rehab in the past, when the Oireachtas did not cover itself in glory. The Oireachtas has not allowed itself to be open to accountability on this issue and how it happened, to be frank. We have to make sure we have enough bandwidth to do what we want to do in terms of the expansion. There are clear areas where there should be expansion in terms of the remit and there are also the issues of the capacity to do it and that the resources are there to do it.

To respond to Deputy Murphy, the biggest move in road safety I experienced as a public representative was when Noel Dempsey, the then Minister for road safety, and the late Gay Byrne established the Road Safety Authority. They were unpopular within the Oireachtas because they proposed a whole range of legislative measures, which came through, on alcohol. I remember those fairly testy times and the reception they got but it worked in terms of the reduced number of deaths. This has been eroded somewhat, particularly post Covid. I do not have the full understanding of it. I believe we need to aggressively go at the road safety issue again, given the increase. We saw recently the report on the paediatric unit, which is very worrying in terms of e-scooters. The level of injuries among children and young people is shocking. We need to re-evaluate this. These are life-limiting injuries, according to the report, and what they are receiving in the hospitals demands reflection from us and, may I suggest, from the committee as well. We need to do more. There is no excuse. It is an unacceptable situation. We had 23,000 individuals failing to surrender their licences when the courts required it. It is extraordinary. The system clearly is not working and it has to change.

We will move on to the next group and the first speaker is Deputy Rice, Chair of the Committee on Health. We will also call Senator Ní Chuilinn, who is Vice Chair of the Committee on Arts, Media, Communications, Culture and Sport committee, and Deputy Maurice Quinlivan, the Chair of the Committee on Disability Matters, will be after that. Each member has two minutes.

Many of the issues discussed this morning will persist until we have an Oireachtas that functions better. I have concerns about the functioning of the Oireachtas, as do others. At our last meeting of committee Chairs, we received a letter signed by 113 civil society organisations highlighting their concerns about the functioning of the Oireachtas. They highlighted that opportunities to contribute remained opaque, inconsistent and difficult to track in a predictable way. They highlighted that we were ranked fourth lowest out of 38 OECD countries in terms of engagement in developing primary legislation. They highlighted the very late notice given of upcoming Bills. I looked at the Oireachtas website and next week's schedule has not yet been published, so it is very hard for people to engage with it. This leads to a lack of accountability and transparency. State bodies are hard to hold to account when Ministers can, at times, be evasive, deflect responsibility and blame others. At times, this culture comes from the top. This is linked to issues with bureaucracy and a lack of productivity. We need to look at ourselves. We often call for productivity from others but we need to look internally. As a new TD, my assessment is that the Oireachtas is often dysfunctional. Take last night, when we sat until 1 a.m. as a matter of normal course with non-emergency business. I wonder what happened to a family-friendly Parliament. As the leader of the largest party and as Taoiseach, the Taoiseach has a role in setting the tone and leading the way as an example in terms of political reform. Political reform has fallen off the agenda. We need better engagement with civil society organisations and we need to enhance how we do our work here.

I welcome the Taoiseach's comments that Ministers will accept amendments. My experience is that the Minister for Health has not accepted a single amendment tabled by Opposition groups so far, so I would welcome a change of tone on that front. Similarly, all Private Members' Bills are dismissed and rejected by the Government and not engaged with in a meaningful way. I welcome the change on this front.

I know the Taoiseach is an avid sports fan and has appreciated our sports stars over the years. There are a few issues I want to bring to the Taoiseach's attention from the Committee on arts, sports, culture and media. I want to raise the issue of a potential tax rebate for some of our Olympic and Paralympic athletes. There is a rebate in place for sports people whereby, on retirement, they can reclaim 40% of their earnings from wages and prize money. This is great for rugby players who have good wages, and maybe for golfers and jockeys who have good prize money, but our Paralympic and Olympic athletes do not earn a wage and they do not win a lot of prize money. Perhaps we could potentially look at a similar rebate, perhaps at a lower rate, for the money they earn from sponsorship. In a lot of cases, this is the bulk of their earnings and they have to pay a huge amount of tax on it. The maximum amount of funding that carded athletes get is €40,000. We are not looking at an awful lot of money to make a living.

The committee also feels very strongly about arts capital funding. One of the recommendations in the report on the development of local and community arts, published during the Thirty-third Dáil, was that the Department would develop an arts capital and equipment programme for investment in local and community arts, with a similar scale and structure as the sports capital grant. On 20 May, the Minister, Deputy O'Donovan, outlined in reply to parliamentary questions that the programme for Government contained a commitment to the arts capital programme. The sports capital programme, as the Taoiseach knows, is brilliant and it is working really well. Our committee would argue it needs to be translated to arts capital funding as well. The Minister, Deputy O'Donovan, detailed that €6 million was allocated for a new programme of capital funding for arts and cultural organisations throughout the country. The maximum grant available is €50,000 and this is not enough when it is considered that some towns do not have dedicated arts centre. Could we get a timeline for the scheme and when it will be deemed that it needs to be expanded?

With regard to the national repository in Swords, the National Museum is in the process of consolidating the majority of its collections in the new facility in Swords, in north County Dublin. The lease on the principal storage space is in place until 2036. Could we be advised on the long-term plan for the storage of Ireland's national treasures?

The ongoing crisis in the assessments of need for children is worsening, with more than 18,000 children waiting for an assessment. In my home place of Limerick, not one child has had an assessment completed within the statutory six months. This is zero out of 259 children. The recent announcement by the Minister for children involving the removal of the requirement for a professional assessment of need report for children to enter special classes has been described by the INTO, the union of the very people who teach and care for these children every single day, as a profound breach of trust. They say they were not consulted or notified of this intended change. They also said teachers were already under intense strain and could not be expected to absorb further major systems change, particularly when those were announced through the media rather than through formal channels of communication. With a formal diagnosis not being needed, will the Taoiseach clarify who will carry out these educational assessments? Will it be the teachers themselves? If so, this is a huge responsibility for those who are not qualified psychologists.

The Taoiseach is very well aware that Cara Darmody is about to finish her second protest outside the Dáil. Her frustration is that the promised recruitment campaign was not advertised or promoted properly. Cara described it as being like the third secret of Fatima. The recruitment call did not work and there is a real need for a new one nationally that is promoted better. If the new campaign is not successful, we need to look at expanding it internationally. Does the Taoiseach agree?

I also want to raise with the Taoiseach the work that has been done by Corpus Christi Primary School in Moyross, Limerick. The school has taken great strides over the past decade and it has become one of the finest schools in the city. It, along with other stakeholders, established The Sky Is The Limit programme.

role.name: Minister for Defence.

paragraphs: We have a strong civil society culture, which is nurtured, supported and funded by the Government in many cases. In contrast with many countries in Europe and internationally, we are one of the more supportive environments for participation in civil society. I do not accept the criticisms Deputy Rice articulated on behalf of some in respect of the Oireachtas, because I am a bit fundamental about the role of elected representatives. In previous Parliaments, there have been criticisms of encroachment on the fundamental role of elected representatives in policy formation and development. The balance has to be right. As individuals, we all engage with civil society and its organisations on an ongoing basis, but the balance has to be that legislation cannot emanate from civil society and perhaps the permanent public service, with all respect to the people on both sides of me. This is an issue. While always facilitating and nurturing civil society, we have to protect the fundamentals of parliamentary democracy in our electoral system.

In the past, I witnessed huge opposition when we developed expansive programmes where elected representatives felt they were outside the loop. That is an ongoing challenge, but I would argue that we are close to and engage regularly with civil society. We are relatively unique in Europe in our electoral system of having parliamentarians who are close to the people on the ground engaging with people on a daily basis. Sometimes when parliamentarians come from other countries, they observe that they see engagement with people fairly regularly and informally.

That said, I agreed last night that it was too late. It invariably happens towards the end of the year. It also happens because of our electoral system and because we are so close to the people. We tend to pack an awful lot into three days of the week. I was not the most popular person in my party when I was in opposition and suggested the Oireachtas should perhaps meet on four or five days of the week. In a previous Oireachtas, we had Friday legislation days. One day would be blocked off for legislation, not for Leaders' Questions and the theatrics that sometimes go on. I am not saying Leaders' Questions is theatrics, but committee members will know what I mean. We would spend one day on legislation and give it time. In other Oireachtas sessions, Private Members' legislation was allowed on a Friday, where an individual parliamentarian might have a particular topic to progress, so I am open to a more family-friendly Parliament. However, there is pressure on everyone in their constituencies, the Parliament, with their international obligations and on the Cathaoirligh of committees and trying to reconcile it all is always problematic. However, the audiovisual room is fairly constant as a facility for civil society. Anyway, we can discuss it another time, but I appreciate the Deputy raising it.
Arts and disability is next.

role.name: Minister for Defence.

paragraphs: I am going through it slowly. I apologise sincerely.

I am supportive of Senator Ní Chuilinn's idea about the Olympics and paralympians. There are perhaps two ways to look at that. From previous experience, I know that the Department of Finance is always reluctant on tax relief and so on, but the Senator's point is valid, that some experience better opportunities through tax relief than others. Paralympians and olympians in general should be looked after and supported because their commitment and dedication and the subsequent roles they play post-Olympics as exemplars for young people and so forth should be rewarded. The precise mechanism we use to reward it is perhaps up for debate but I would support that, particularly the sponsorship earnings issue.

On the arts capital funding, many local authorities have developed strong arts officers and arts programmes. In my early political life, I was chair of the arts committee of my local authority and it was probably one of the best experiences I have ever had. We were lucky that it was a local authority that had a positive view of the arts. We did a lot locally in partnership with the Arts Council. I favour that and I will talk to the Minister about timelines. However, we should not lose the core funding for the national cultural institutions and the Arts Council, which has been transformative historically in the arts. I will engage with the National Museum on its collection - there needs to be permanency - and on how the collection gets used better regionally and locally.

We have made great strides on archives as well. Tomorrow night, I will be honouring my late mentor Professor Dermot Keogh, who was a stickler for archives as a historian and did a lot to push the Department of foreign affairs and other Departments to create the foreign affairs series, digitise and collect archives and so on. The committee will find me and the Department of An Taoiseach supportive of any suggestions it has in that regard.

We dealt with assessment of need yesterday in the House. We have to change the current system. It is simply not fit for purpose at the moment and we need to prioritise the provision of therapists for services for children. Teachers will not be doing the assessments, but there is a whole series of measures the Minister outlined for the autism panels and the pathway, for example, for autism. There will be assessment officers. It has to change. It is not tenable in its current format, particularly since the High Court decisions. I am clear about that, but Deputy Quinlivan's side-----
Just-----
Our time is up.

role.name: Minister for Defence.

paragraphs: I did not interrupt. We have also initiated a schools-based therapy service, which we made a red line issue. Going into the general election, I said I wanted that to be done. All parties in the Government are committed to it and the Ministers, Deputies McEntee and Naughton, and the Minister of State, Deputy Moynihan, have gone ahead of schedule with it. It will be in place in the new year in special schools and completed in special schools from September. It will then be expanded into mainstream schools. That is a service to have multidisciplinary teams in schools, but we will come back to the Deputy in detail about all of that.

We will move on to the next group, comprising Deputy John Paul O'Shea, Cathaoirleach of the Committee on Social Protection, Rural and Community Development; Deputy Brian Brennan, Leas-Chathaoirleach of the Committee on Enterprise, Tourism and Employment; and Deputy Naoise Ó Cearúil, Leas-Chathaoirleach of the Committee on Irish Language, Gaeltacht and the Irish Speaking Community, in that sequence. They have two minutes.

Míle buíochas. I thank the Taoiseach. As Cathaoirleach of the Committee on Social Protection, Rural and Community Development, I have two questions, one to address each of the respective areas. The first question is about social protection.

The committee has engaged on a policy and legislative level with the Minister and Department on auto-enrolment. With the launch of the saving scheme imminent, what impact will the scheme have? It is a fundamental initiative in the social protection domain, which will help current and future generations. We know about the demographic challenge facing the country, that three times the current number of people will retire in 25 years, with less than one third of the workforce available to fund pension payments going forward. In what way will the new scheme support better financial security for workers in their later years and promote overall economic stability?

Turning to rural and community development and the Gaeltacht, the committee has been actively engaging with community groups and stakeholders, first, as part of its review of pre-budget submissions and, second, as part of its review of Our Rural Future: Rural Development Policy 2021-2025 and its successor strategy from 2025 to 2030. A key issue that arose in those engagements was the multi-annual funding and budgets to be provided to the many community bodies that contribute to communities. Related to this, the European Commission has published its proposals, including €2 trillion in commitments for the 2028-2034 period. There has been much debate about the proposal on the integration of rural development into broader cohesion funds. On one hand, I welcome the simplification in this ethos. Anything that simplifies the access to funding and reduces the administration hurdles is to be welcomed.

However, concerns exist, for example, particularly around the future of the LEADER programme. LEADER has been instrumental in supporting local community groups, private enterprises, jobs and services in rural Ireland. How does the Taoiseach intend to advocate at EU level for the continued prioritisation of rural development funding and the LEADER programme?

In light of the current geopolitical situation and the uncertainty of the American market, can the Taoiseach outline the Government's plans for the new markets? While we welcome the trade with America, we are well aware there are less than 400 million people living there. When you look at populations such as China with 1.4 billion and India with 1.46 billion, what are we doing to attack these markets? We need to engage with these countries and encourage our trade relations and expansion in these markets.

For tourism, I am hugely concerned about the lack of hotels being built in rural Ireland. Currently, it is simply not feasible to build a hotel in rural Ireland. This sector needs to be stimulated. I am passionate about it from my previous background and what this sector is doing for communities. It employs over 100 people in an average hotel, gives an influx of tourists for 365 days of the year and provides business opportunities for local shops and suppliers, but there is also a social aspect.

When I was in a hotel, you took on young people. You got them off their phones and in making money, meeting people and learning how to communicate. You simply cannot put a price on that nowadays. If you were to take two towns - and I am not going to be parochial about this - and you look at Gorey and the success of the town, it has four hotels. I worked out there were 1,200 people coming into the town every weekend. If you go up the road to Wicklow town, it lost a hotel and that has had a devastating effect on the town.

The last question relates to the cap at Dublin Airport. What is the current position of Government on that? It is not necessary; it is simply essential. We must maintain our push to increase the cap to 40 million and we are looking at the forecast going forward, with 60 million people coming in. That will have a huge and positive effect on the tourist industry.

De ghnáth, oibrímid trí Ghaeilge sa choiste, ach don chruinniú seo labhróidh mé i mBéarla. Usually, we work through the Irish language but for this meeting, I will speak in English so everybody can understand.
