The Chair of the committee, Catherine Connolly, was elected President, so I have been in the Chair, I suppose, since September. We have also been without a researcher. We have one starting in the new year but that has held back some of the committee's work.

The primary focus of the committee has been on the objective that 20% of the new workforce in the public service will be competent and able to work through the Irish language. Many of the witnesses coming before us from the various Departments have come forth without a plan. I ask the Department of the Taoiseach, in particular, to oversee the drive to ensure we reach this particular milestone by 2030, as it goes into every single Department and is not just kept within education or the Irish language.

Another aspect we are focusing on as part of this is learning from contemporaries, particularly in Wales and what it has done in the third level and second level sectors. We will be going to Wales in February to learn from them.

Another thing to bring to the Taoiseach's attention is to note there has been a welcome increase in funding for the Irish language and Gaeltacht, particularly in the most recent budget. Looking at comparable Departments, however, it has not grown in tandem. We ask that future budgets look at percentage increases towards Irish language and Gaeltacht that are similar to the arts, for example, heritage and comparable departments.
I will reduce the Taoiseach's time from four minutes to three minutes. Otherwise, some people may not get in to talk.

role.name: Minister for Defence.

paragraphs: In response to Deputy O'Shea, auto-enrolment is one of the most transformative things we are doing as a Government. It has been a long time in gestation and we were working on it in the previous Government. It is estimated 750,000 to 800,000 workers currently have no pension provision and this is critical in the future to provide pension provision. Close to over 400,000 people have registered so far which is a very good start. I ask everyone to work with it. People will complain about this, that and the other but it is essential for the workers concerned and for the long-term viability of the country with the demographic changes and so on.

I hear the Deputy on the multi-annual financial framework. This is a big issue for Ireland and I am not too sure it is appreciated by Members of the Oireachtas just how big an issue this is. We have to negotiate hard and strong with the Commission and with other member states on this. We are a net contributor but we have big issues with the Common Agriculture Policy, Horizon and with rural and LEADER funding.

Regarding Deputy Brian Brennan's point on new markets, the European Union is 100% going after this with engagements with Australia and India and is hoping to conclude a deal, as well as in respect of Asia and Indonesia. It is ramping up the trade deals to counteract the US protectionism or tariff imposition by the US. We can do more trade deals. Interestingly, 72% of all trade is still under the World Trade Organization, WTO, frameworks, which is down from about 80%. The world has not collapsed and it is important to bear that in mind. As regards the cap in Dublin Airport, the Minister is bringing in comprehensive legislation to deal with that.

Regarding hotels, these are a vital economic developer. They depend on other economic variables, purchasing power in an area and so on, but they are a critical piece and asset to a town or area. They bring more people in. It is a chicken and an egg in many respects but if you do get a hotel in, it is great.

An rud is tábhachtaí ba mhaith liom a rá leis an Teachta Ó Cearúil ar dtús ná tá i bhfad níos mó daoine ag labhairt na Gaeilge sa daonra inniu ná mar a bhí i 1922, nuair a fuaireamar ár neamhspleáchas. A lot more are speaking Irish today than there were in 1922, which is a good sign. On supporting Gaelscoileanna, Deputy Ó Cearúil is correct that Wales is a very good example of constant innovation. At the British-Irish Parliamentary Assembly, it was creative industries Wales was pursuing and with the Welsh language, they have been very impactful and effective. We can do the same with "An Cailín Ciún" and other developments. There is great interest now in the creative industries in the Irish language. Ukraine asked us about identity and language and how they cultivate it in the context of its issues. Those are areas where Ireland can make an intelligent and informed contribution on how to approach language and so on. I hear the Deputy on the annual funding and I wish him well. His enthusiasm for the Irish language cannot be questioned.

The next speaker is Deputy Ó Muirí, who chairs the climate, environment and energy committee. I will then call Deputy O'Reilly, who is Chair of the public petitions and ombudsman committee, and Deputy Dempsey, who is Vice Chair of the children and equality committee. In that sequence, they will have two minutes each.
Níl agam ach dhá nóiméad. Tá mé chun dhá cheist shonracha a chur ar an Taoiseach.

As Chair of the climate committee, we are interested in the development of offshore renewable energy, which will need dedicated marshalling ports. We heard from the sector on the upcoming review of the national ports policy that this is important, particularly for the sector's development. There is concern that large investment is required for ports and may require State investment. Port policy may preclude that in the way it is being developed. Is this being considered by the Government in the context of that very important development?

On the environmental side, we heard about the Blackwater fish kill, which I am sure the Taoiseach is familiar with, and the illegal turf cutting and peat extraction in the midlands and the west. The common theme was there is blatant disregard for regulations and those agencies responsible for enforcing them are really struggling to enforce. The inland fisheries are looking for additional powers to prosecute at higher courts and the councils have not secured a single injunction or conviction for illegal peat extraction, which entails €40 million worth of irreplaceable peat effectively going abroad per annum. Is the Taoiseach concerned, from a Government perspective, on that front? How can Government sharpen the teeth of the regulators to give them more powers to deal with this?
I call Deputy O'Reilly.
I thank the Cathaoirleach for facilitating the swap. I have to go to the Chamber.

I thank the Taoiseach for being here with us. I have a broad point for him on the number of women who chair committees. Without meaning to be party political about it, there is one party whose committee Chairs are all men. The phrase "Can't see, can't be" is not in currency for no reason. I ask the Taoiseach to examine composition. We have a couple of Leas-Chathaoirligh here today who may be taking the bad look off things or making things look a little better than they are. I mean no disrespect to them. We have an issue with regard to women representatives. The Government in particular has an issue. The Opposition, my party in particular, is doing a lot of the heavy lifting in terms of women Chairs. I am the Chair of the Joint Committee on Public Petitions and the Ombudsmen. It is a very busy one. I thank the team I work with, including Alex, Martha and Brian. They are a fantastic bunch of people.

My committee has discussed issues such as flooding in east Cork, pension entitlements for same-sex couples and the treatment of pet theft. By the time people come to the petitions committee, they are often incredibly frustrated by what could generally be called bureaucracy or officialdom. Usually, the people we see have been through every procedure and have done everything correctly. It is frustrating, as the Chair of the committee, to see that when we correspond and make recommendations, they seem to go into something of a void. That picks up a point made by Deputy Ward on the standing of recommendations of committees and the question of what we can do as committee Chairs to ensure recommendations we make are acted on. It would be very simple to say everything should go through the Department of the Taoiseach, because that is the way things might get done, but that is not the answer either. By the time people come to the petitions committee, they have exhausted every possible avenue and are incredibly frustrated. They might have a case or might not but they do not have anyone to say "Yes" or "No" to them and we can bounce around quite a bit. Therefore, any advice or steer the Taoiseach can give in this regard would be appreciated.
I call Deputy Aisling Dempsey.

I thank the Taoiseach for being here. I am here in my role as Leas-Chathaoirleach of the Joint Committee on Children and Equality in the unavoidable absence of our Cathaoirleach, Deputy Keira Keogh. I am delighted to be here.

At recent public meetings, the Joint Committee on Children and Equality examined the priority policy areas of child poverty and deprivation, child protection matters, and the use of special emergency accommodation. The committee will soon commence a series of public meetings on the topic of technology, social media and children, with a focus on the safety and well-being of children online. It is also the intention of the committee to consider, in 2026, the topic of the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child into Irish law. The Taoiseach will agree with me that every child in Ireland deserves a happy, healthy and safe childhood, with equal opportunities to thrive and succeed, regardless of where they start in life.

A recurring theme evident from the examination of the policy priorities by our committee to date is the need for strengthened interagency work and collaboration. Robust interagency collaboration is essential for the delivery of services to ensure the safety, well-being and welfare of Ireland's children, to protect the most vulnerable children and families in society and to enable better outcomes for children and young people with complex needs. Could the Taoiseach please provide an outline as to how interagency work will be delivered during the lifetime of this Government and the timeframe in which robust interagency working will be achieved? This is essential to ensure the experience of children growing up in Ireland is a positive one for all and to support the delivery of services to ensure proper safeguarding and protection of children.
The Taoiseach has three minutes.

role.name: Minister for Defence.

paragraphs: Gabhaim buíochas leis an Teachta Ó Muirí. Offshore renewable energy is essential to our climate goals and so on. This morning again, I attended a clearing house meeting, chaired by my Secretary General, with the industry, regulators and Departments to identify barriers and so forth.

On national ports policy, the Deputy is right in that there is an issue. The core policy has been that ports must be able to wipe their faces financially or be commercially viable. Some ports, such as the Port of Cork, have been successful in getting European and Ireland Strategic Investment Fund funding for the development of infrastructure for offshore renewable energy development. Belfast has been very successful. We now have two ports that will likely be able to facilitate large-scale renewables projects. We need more. The ports policy has to take that into account. The issue of investment must be considered. The ports' turnover and profit margins do not seem to be at a level that could sustain the higher capital requirements to deal with offshore renewables.

Security is also an issue. We have not really factored security considerations into port policy and port development. Considering that 80% of all trade goes through Dublin Port, any disruption to Dublin Port is a huge disruption to the Irish economy. I have asked the relevant Minister and Department to factor security considerations into the development of port policy. There is a shadow fleet operated by Russia, and some of its vessels are environmental time bombs that could be very problematic for our waters, for example. It is an issue.
The Deputy made a very good point on peatland extraction. What is happening is not good enough. I will reflect on what the Deputy is saying, and we will see where we can enhance enforcement.

On the Blackwater, I was very disappointed that the source of what was a huge pollution incident could not be found. It was highly disruptive to biodiversity and marine life in the area. That is a huge issue.

I take Deputy Louise O'Reilly's point. Again, we select according to the D'Hondt system. It all depends on the committees. Some people have a particular interest in some committees, but I hear what the Deputy is saying. It is a matter for each political party.
Flooding in east Cork is also of interest to me.
I thought it might be.

role.name: Minister for Defence.

paragraphs: The Deputy got my memory going again. I was down there on a number of occasions to see the flooding. It continues to be a huge issue.

We will reflect on what the Deputy said. I do not want to make a knee-jerk response. The Deputy made the point that although the petitioners come to her committee, it is a question of what happens afterwards and of who engages meaningfully with petitioners in respect of issues. I will examine this with my team and see whether we can develop a mechanism to follow through on the issues that arise.
I appreciate the work the Deputy has been doing. I would imagine it involves a very wide-ranging compass.

Deputy Dempsey referred to children and equality. Safety online is a key issue for parents. Parents want help and the State to intervene to protect children and to support them in protecting children from algorithms and the whole social media revolution. She is right about children deserving a happy childhood.

I realise many people complained about the pouches when we introduced them last year. Four hundred and sixty-two schools have now drawn down the money. One teacher said to me that the children can be heard again in the corridors. I was shocked. In other words, the children are shouting and roaring in the corridors again.

No one should have a mobile phone at a meeting. I am serious. I bring no mobile phone with me to meetings. I am not referring to any Member present. I bring no mobile phone to Cabinet meetings. If you have a mobile phone, you are not concentrating, focusing on the issues or listening to your colleagues articulating points. We provided the pouches in schools.
We are moving on.

role.name: Minister for Defence.

paragraphs: Have I answered every question? There was one on interagency work. Interagency work is key. The Cabinet subcommittee system is a mechanism. It is hard going and there are many subcommittees, but they bring people together. We had Tusla before the Cabinet subcommittee on children recently. It was very effective, and we got a very good insight into the work of Tusla and its challenges.

I thank the Taoiseach. We are now moving on to Deputy Erin McGreehan, who is Chair of the Joint Committee on Further and Higher Education, Research, Innovation and Science, Deputy Conor McGuinness, who is Chair of the Joint Committee on Fisheries and Maritime Affairs, and Deputy Malcolm Byrne, who is Chair of the Joint Committee on Artificial Intelligence. They have two minutes each and will be taken in the sequence in which I have mentioned them.

I thank the Taoiseach very much for being here. The priorities of the Department of Further and Higher Education, Research, Innovation and Science are central to Ireland's long-term economic strength, social mobility and innovation capacity. As we all know, they shape the opportunities available to our learners, researchers and workers across the entire country. Looking ahead, we need a system that is responsive, more ambitious, more flexible, more inclusive and capable of delivering the talent and research ecosystem required in a modern country and the growing economy we demand. Considering the global economic turbulence, there are gaps domestically. We need considerable funding ambition in the Department. Areas of significant importance are access and capacity within the system, the substantial expansion of places, and research and innovation.
We need to significantly scale up the national research fund and innovation hubs, etc.

I raise skills and the workforce. There are acute shortages in healthcare, construction, digital technology and green skills. Inclusion, disability and mental health supports are persistent barriers to education. We need to invest in infrastructure, including campus development and student accommodation. Apprenticeships need a huge increase in investment. I also raise the shared island unit and the huge role it can have, particularly in Dundalk, with the development of the first all-Ireland university with linkage between Queen's University Belfast and DkIT. I am ambitious for this and I look forward to seeing how the shared island unit can invest in Louth.

I will run through three of the biggest items that the fisheries and maritime affairs committee has been dealing with over the past number of months. The first will come as no surprise to the Taoiseach today. The December Council begins and the fisheries quota negotiations for next year are under way. The entire committee and I were adamant that these negotiations needed a whole-of-government approach. We have said as much to the Minister of State, Deputy Dooley on several occasions. The industry is in freefall. The Taoiseach met with fishing industry representatives fairly recently. These negotiations are make or break for the fishing industry in Ireland and for our coastal communities. What we need is the Taoiseach as the Head of Government to play a role in these negotiations. A Minister is going over there against larger countries with larger fishing interests with senior Ministers around the table. Negotiating in a silo is not going to cut it to extract the concessions, the Hague preferences and the additional quota that we need. We need the Taoiseach as the head of Government and a whole-of-government approach. What will the Taoiseach be doing today and tomorrow to assist in those negotiations?

The Sea-Fisheries Protection Authority, SFPA, was before the committee recently. It was utterly unsatisfactory in how it engaged with the committee. The SFPA is part of a wider piece of work that we are doing on sea fisheries protection more broadly. My colleague Deputy Pádraig Mac Lochlainn is rapporteur on that. I do not want to pre-empt his recommendations in that report that he will bring before the committee early in the new year, but picking up the mood of the committee members and my own assessment is that there is a deficit when it comes to accountability and transparency from that particular agency. That will necessitate legislative change. I would like the Taoiseach to look at that and to be supportive of those committee recommendations when they do come in the new year and to legislative.

He mentioned offshore renewable energy in his opening statement. What will he do to ensure codesign is at the very core of how offshore renewable energy is developed and that rather than going down the extractive and exploitative model of energy generation off our coast, we have one that benefits coastal communities and ensures that coastal communities that bear the greatest impact of this infrastructure and development get the greatest dividend?

I thank the Taoiseach for being with us today. The Joint Committee on Artificial Intelligence is grateful for the support of our secretariat and to the Minister of State, Deputy Niamh Smyth and her officials. We will issue a short report next week, which will make a number of recommendations about how the Government should support the use of AI responsibly but about how the Government itself should adapt and integrate it into government processes to deliver public services more effectively and efficiently. It is critical that we get the right balance between regulation and innovation. What is important in terms of our asks of the Taoiseach is to continue to provide leadership in this space, that the AI office, which will be established next year, will not be a thou shalt not office but one that will be facilitative and support SMEs and civic society organisations to meet their obligations under the AI Act, but also to ensure that Ireland becomes a leader in the adoption of AI in a safe way.

Our committee is also going to support the setting up of an AI observatory, which has a lot of supports, which is an evidence-based, research-led institution that will examine the potential impact of AI on aspects of society and the economy and ensuring that where there is displacement in employment we upskill and reskill. We are aware that the Minister, Deputy Lawless is going to be bringing a number of proposals in that regard. We think it is critical that there is investment in upskilling and reskilling. As part of the EU Presidency, we want to ensure that Ireland positions itself as an AI leader but that in Europe's competitiveness agenda using technology and AI is a key part of that. We welcome the commitment to the AI summit that will be held by the Government in October. We hope that the Taoiseach will attend. We would like to hope that as many heads of Government would be able to attend at the summit as well.

role.name: Minister for Defence.

paragraphs: I will respond to Deputy McGreehan first. The third and fourth level sectors are central to economic development in this country. It is one of the reasons I initiated the establishment of the Department of higher education in 2020. It has the capacity to underpin future innovation and economic development. Research is key. The INSPIRE programme that the Minister, Deputy Lawless has announced recently represents the step change that I wanted this Department to engage in in the research space. It builds on the PRTLI model of an earlier period in the late 1990s and early 2000s. It will be critical in building a research infrastructure in universities. Universities are adapting a whole range of skills. The Deputy referred to green skills. There are also mental health supports within campuses. I am quite impressed with some campuses where there are better spaces, in terms of people who need to take time out of the hustle and bustle and all the noise and so on. We always need to watch the mental health supports in universities and further education that they are there for the students on an ongoing basis.

On the situation in the shared island, the Queen's University and Dundalk initiative is a significant development. It is important for Dundalk because it was not part of others in the technological university sector. Here is an opportunity now for both colleges to get together and go through governance frameworks and all the necessary work that has to be done. The shared island unit stands ready to support that initiative and to be supportive of it. It is important to get the framework right and all of that. This is a great opportunity. I know the Deputy has been passionately advocating for this. We will take that on board.

Deputy McGuinness spoke about fisheries. It is a core issue. I met with the group. To be frank, I engage with the Commission on a whole range of issues. We have to maintain a constructive relationship with the Commission. I have spoken to President von der Leyen in respect of the derogation on nitrates and the entirety of issues in agriculture. We will have to engage with the Commission on fishing. ICES research is saying it is overfished not by us, but by others that the European Union engages with. Non-EU countries are overfishing the entire area. It will mean a 70% reduction in the pelagic catch. That is on top of a 20% reduction as a result of Brexit. This is existential for the industry. We are going to have to go back to the Commission in respect of whatever supports we want to give from our Exchequer, which, at the moment, would have to take on board state aid rules, which I understand from talking to officials are quite restrictive in respect of what states can do. Given the exceptional nature of what is hitting the industry, we are going to have to be innovative and responsive.

The Minister of State, Deputy Dooley, and the Minister, Deputy Heydon, are negotiating now in terms of the Fisheries Council. It is beyond that in terms of the scale and impact. I take the Deputy's point. I am aware of that. Deputy Pat the Cope Gallagher and all the Deputies in Donegal, west Cork and coastal communities more generally are concerned about this because the impact on those communities will be significant. There are large concentrations of employment in Donegal, Castletownbere, Waterford, Wexford and so forth. We will await the outcome in terms of what the committee is proposing in respect of the authorities on transparency and all of that.

On offshore, the Deputy can use the terms exploitative or extractive, but we need offshore renewable energy. Coastal communities should benefit and there should be a dividend for them. We have to go for it. If we do not, we are in real trouble energy-wise, climate-wise and everything else.

Deputy Malcolm Byrne referenced AI, which connects in to the offshore issue. Our commitment to AI and our capacity to adopt AI will be dependent on having sufficient energy resources because AI is energy intensive. In terms of large energy users, future foreign direct investment will be critical. Regarding the Deputy's point on Government public services, we look forward to his committee's recommendations. I agree with his first-class idea around AI observatories. What we need to do, very quickly, is monitor the employment patterns because already there are signs that it is beginning to manifest itself in some parts of the economy. We need real-time monitoring of what is happening in terms of AI's impact on the jobs market. An interesting report we got from the expert group on future skills needs indicates that Ireland is actually very high on skill levels and our AI competency per capita is one of the highest across Europe but we need to build on that. That is a good news story but areas like energy are less so.

Public service adoption of AI is critical, as the Deputy said. We are working on enhancing digital public services and supporting enterprises to accelerate their use of digital technologies. There is a whole programme on digital public services aimed at 100% digitisation of key public services and driving responsible AI adoption across the public sector. The Minister for Public Expenditure, Infrastructure, Public Service Reform and Digitalisation, Deputy Chambers, has a significant programme in that area, again related to productivity gains within the public sector and better delivery of public services. We want to be a location of choice for ethical AI and digital start-ups and a global hub for innovation.

I take the Deputy's point about the balance between regulation and innovation and that is something we have to work very hard on. The perception is that in Europe the balance is on the regulatory side as opposed to the innovative side. The Commission is trying to correct that with its investment announcements in respect of AI factories and so on. We are trying to piggy-back onto that and be part of that process. It is a transformative area, of that there is no doubt. There will be bumps along the way and highs and lows in respect of this but there is no doubt that the technology will improve, refine and develop. We cannot just put our heads in the sand. We cannot put our heads in the sand in relation to data centres either. We have issues now in terms of energy but data centres are not the great evil. They are a reality of modern life and modern societies and economies globally. That is just a reality but there are limits to what the grid can do at any one time. That is why the offshore wind revolution has to happen. Ireland is probably one of the leaders in integrating renewables onto the grid because of our experience in onshore wind and because of our work in solar. The Oireachtas needs to grapple with this too. When I am in the Dáil, I hear comments about that wind farm, that gas station or that anaerobic digestion facility but equally, we have a more national problem of how to replace fossil fuels with renewables. It is a real challenge for everybody because we must have energy to run the country and to maintain people's high-quality livelihoods.
I have said enough, I apologise. I thought that was the last foray but I see Deputy Gannon lurking menacingly.

There are three final questioners but the Taoiseach only has ten more minutes because he has another commitment. Deputy Conway-Walsh, Chair of the Joint Committee on Defence and National Security is next, followed by Deputy Gannon, Chair of the drugs use committee and then Senator Mark Daly, Cathaoirleach of the Seanad Select Committee on EU Scrutiny and Transparency and each contributor has two minutes.

I assure the Taoiseach that we have plenty of energy on the defence and national security committee. This morning we spent time out at the National Cyber Security Centre and I want to acknowledge the great work being done there and thank the centre for hosting us this morning. I welcome the increased funding to address the decades of neglect of our Defence Forces. Oireachtas oversight of national security has never been more urgently needed, especially with Ireland's upcoming EU Presidency and the pending national security strategy. We are lucky that we have an excellent committee comprised of members, both Government and non-Government, with huge experience within the Defence Forces and they take their responsibilities really seriously. Following efforts to examine areas within national security policy, the committee has found that its current remit does not allow proper examination of this policy area. The key stakeholders in the area of national security such as the Taoiseach's Department and An Garda Síochána have both declined invitations to attend meetings of the committee on the basis that its remit does not extend to aspects of national security policy under the control of the committee.

At recent meetings the committee agreed to draft a request to the committee on procedure to seek an extension of its remit to fully cover national security. The committee has found that under its current narrow remit in relation to national security it cannot provide oversight and adequately examine this critical policy area which is included in the committee's name. The committee is seeking to have its remit extended to cover all aspects of national security. As per Dáil Éireann Standing Order 109(3), the committee has reviewed its procedures and its role and is making the request in this context. The committee also notes that other sectoral committees, such as the Joint Committee on Fisheries and Maritime Affairs, have a remit which covers aspects of more than one Department. The committee considers that given that national security is in its title, its remit should extend to all aspects of oversight in the area and not just those under the Department of Defence. I am sure the Taoiseach understands what I am saying and I ask him to have a look at this issue in the context of the geopolitical turbulence and challenges that we are all facing. He said he was very much in favour of protecting the fundamentals of parliamentary democracy and in that vein, I ask him to look at the remit of the defence and national security committee and to enable us to do the job that needs to be done.

I thank the Taoiseach for joining us today. I chair the Joint Committee on Drugs Use. It was formed following the Citizen's Assembly on Drug Use, which was chaired by Mr. Paul Reid. That assembly engaged in the most comprehensive analysis and exploration of drug use in the history of this State. Our committee has a nine-month duration and is putting flesh on the bones of the work of the citizen's assembly. Our committee will report in June but the national drugs strategy is due to be released in draft form in January. We have talked to the Minister of State with responsibility in this area, Deputy Murnane O'Connor, who has agreed to more engagement with the committee in terms of its input to the strategy. I wanted to reference that with the Taoiseach and put it on the record.

One of the issues that we are currently dealing with that is incredibly important is drug-related intimidation, violence and coercion. There are very few communities the length and breadth of Ireland that have not been affected in some form by drug-related intimidation. We saw that in its most hideous, extreme and tragic form last weekend in County Offaly and it is something that all of us must work to confront. These gangs are enforcing intimidation and violence on communities. The stories that we have heard at the committee from the communities that are engaging with us are terrifying, they are real and they require an immediate response.

I thank the Taoiseach for being here. I also thank him and Mr. Diarmuid Lynch for their support for the establishment of the EU scrutiny committee back in 2022. The Cabinet made the decision on 12 July that year to establish the committee, which goes to the point he made about gold-plated EU rules and regulations and the examination of those. That committee's original title was the committee for the scrutiny of EU-related draft statutory instruments but we have tightened it up and it is now the committee on EU scrutiny and transparency. The work of the committee includes getting the draft statutory instruments before the Minister signs them and making sure they are passed on to the relevant sectoral committees to give them an opportunity to scrutinise them in advance of them being signed. It also includes examining issues that would affect us in relation to the Windsor Framework or the impact of EU proposals on legislation that would impact our relationship with our big trading partners such the UK, EU, US and Canada. It also includes the big issue of fines. I will give the Taoiseach an example. This is the directive that came in on organ donation. It is 16 pages long. By the time the Department of Health was finished adding to it, the document was 36 pages long. It had to be amended subsequently because it was so badly drafted.

That was highlighted by the Irish Kidney Association. Another six pages were added so 42 pages of legislation never went to the health committee and it was the first ever legislation on organ donation in the history of the State. Health committee TDs and Senators never saw it.

The other issue we look at is that of fines. Most recently, we paid a fine of €1.5 million for the late transposition or adoption of the legislation on work-life balance. The last time, the committee - and this is the ask - only got five draft Bills out of a few hundred. So far, we have only received one. The committee is meeting next week in the Seanad Chamber. I will write to the Taoiseach and the committee will write to Departments to ask them to comply with the Cabinet decision that we get the draft statutory instruments - not just us, but that we would be able to pass them on to the various sectoral committees to give them an opportunity to scrutinise them in advance. That is, first, so we do not incur fines but, second, that democratic oversight actually takes place when it comes to what about amounts to more legislation than what the Dáil actually passes.
Can the Taoiseach respond to those? I am conscious that he has be somewhere in five minutes.

role.name: Minister for Defence.

paragraphs: I appreciate the comments Deputy Conway-Walsh made. The Oireachtas sets the criteria; I think the Deputy has now referred it to the procedural committee. I will reflect on what she said. This is a first in regard to national security. We have not had a culture in the Oireachtas for dealing with national security issues like other parliaments historically have. We have to be conscious of confidentiality requirements in respect of what can be revealed at any given public meeting in respect of security. It could create unintended vulnerabilities.
I completely understand that-----

role.name: Minister for Defence.

paragraphs: The Deputy might let me finish. I will certainly reflect on it and I would be interested in what the procedural committee's view on it is as well. There would have to be responses from what at the moment would be the Department of Defence. It should be responding to the Deputy.
It is.

role.name: Minister for Defence.

paragraphs: It is. Fair enough. I am glad the Deputy was at the National Cyber Security Centre. It is a very good centre and we have made huge progress in respect of cybersecurity in the past five years. I will reflect on what she said and come back to her in the context of her desires and that of the committee to broaden its remit.

Deputy Gannon spoke about drug use. I will talk to the Minister of State, Deputy Murnane O'Connor, on what he has focused in on and to make sure that happens in respect of national strategy. He is correct that the intimidation, coercion and fear are big worries, when people see people dealing on the streets and creating their territory. It is injurious to normal life and the quality of normal life. It creates a fear and tension in communities and there has been violence and aggression. In many ways, it is an informal subjugation of a community. We will talk to the Garda in regard to a tougher line on this. We are constantly increasing the numbers of gardaí. There is already a steady throughput in Templemore that is enhancing our capacity to police in a more visible way on our streets. That is an important dimension to it as well.

On the EU scrutiny committee, I know it has been a lifelong commitment of the Cathaoirleach of the Seanad, Senator Daly. We will discuss that with the respective committees in regard to what is coming before the committee. There are maybe two areas where there is huge and significant simplification going on with legislation at European level. Sometimes we look at all of this as a fait accompli. We are looking at the end of a cycle and maybe we need to look at stuff earlier in the cycle to see if we can make inputs before it becomes a directive and before we are at the legislative transposition stage. Invariably, when that happens, we are up against a clock that is ticking in regard to fines and public servants are saying if we do not get this over, we could risk a fine. There is new agenda now, however, in regard to simplification, and a desire to try and reduce regulation to some degree in various industries and sectors of the economy. Maybe that is something we should intervene early on. There is a reverse way of looking at this.
I thank the Taoiseach.

To conclude, I wish to thank the Taoiseach, his officials and all the committee cathaoirligh. Some 24 people contributed here as cathaoirligh of Oireachtas committees. A huge number of areas were covered and today's engagement highlights the breadth of work of the Oireachtas committees, the members and the staff who work with our committees.

sections.title: Saincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Debate

paragraphs: I rise deeply saddened by the horrific murders that occurred in Edenderry on Saturday evening. Two innocent lives were taken - Mary Holt, aged 60, and four-year-old Tadhg Farrell. I wish to pay my respects to Mary and Tadhg. May they both rest in peace and may their memory guide our response through this moment of darkness. I visited the scene and it is something I will never forget. A room recently alive with an excited young heart giddy with the joy of Christmas, toys imagined, stockings planned and innocence undisturbed now stands as a haunting reminder of a future robbed. The silence was heavy. The air felt cold carrying the memory of a terror no child should ever face.

The people of Edenderry are not just grieving, they are angry, heartbroken, traumatised and confused. I firmly believe the true weight of this tragedy will fall most painfully when the town sees a tiny white coffin - heartbreakingly small - carried to its final premature resting place. In that moment, the darkness of what has happened will become real in a way none of us ever wished to witness.

This did not come from nowhere. This is down to drugs and the drugs trade. It is glamorised in music, film, social media and entertainment. It is portrayed as fast money, status, power and designer labels. Hard working people see individuals who have never worked a day in their lives live with the trappings of wealth. They ask themselves, "What am I doing wrong?" Young people see this and believe it is success. However, the truth is not glamour. It is terror, drug debt, threats, children being groomed into criminality. It is soulless, selling misery, addiction and violence for profit. It destroys families, businesses, relationship and hope. It underpins so many of the issues we debate in this Chamber - housing, poverty, mental health, domestic abuse, crime and inequality. The raw reality of that world without filters or fantasy burnt a four-year-old child alive on Saturday. That is the cost; that is the truth.

While nothing can undo this tragedy, we can influence what happens next. I have complete confidence in the gardaí. They will find those responsible. When they do, the full weight of the law must land heavily on them. Justice must be seen, and justice must be felt. However, justice must also mean prevention. It must mean restoring confidence, protecting children and rebuilding peace.

I sincerely acknowledge the work the Minister for justice is doing in his Department in terms of gardaí recruitment. It matters and I thank him for that. However, given what has happened in Edenderry, I ask the Minister to request the Garda Commissioner to examine the establishment of a dedicated task force for Edenderry focused specifically on dismantling drug-driven criminality. I am not directing but I am respectfully asking that it be considered.

People deserve protection in life, not only in law. They deserve peace in their homes and on their streets. They deserve the right to enjoy the simple things like sitting in their own sitting room to watch television without fear. We owe that to Mary and little Tadhg. We owe that to every resident in Edenderry.

role.name: Minister of State at the Department of Culture, Communications and Sport

speeches.speakerLabel: Minister of State at the Department of Culture, Communications and Sport (Deputy Charlie McConalogue)
paragraphs: I thank the Deputy for raising this. On behalf of the Minister for Justice, Home Affairs and Migration, I thank him for addressing it on the floor of the Dáil. I join the Minister, Taoiseach and the Deputy in strongly condemning the deliberate callous attack on the house in Edenderry, County Offaly, over the weekend which tragically resulted in the loss of the lives of Mary Holt and young Tadhg Farrell. I join with the Deputy in extending my deepest sympathies to the family and friends of Mary and young Tadhg on this absolutely unacceptable travesty and loss of life. There is no place in a civilised society for such heinous violence.

An Garda Síochána has commenced a murder investigation into all the circumstances surrounding this fatal attack. I join An Garda Síochána in appealing to anyone with information to come forward. The gardaí have given assurances they will relentlessly pursue the violent and dangerous criminals for this murderous attack. They will be brought to justice. I appreciate that this incident will be shocking to people in the community in Edenderry and across the country and may naturally give them pause for concern about their own safety. I reassure them that the gardaí are following a direct line of inquiry and they have a strong record of bringing dangerous and violent criminals to justice.

It has been well reported that gardaí suspect criminals involved in the drugs trade in the midlands may be behind the most heinous act. Tackling the scourge of drug dealing and targeting the work of organised crime groups who inflict intimidation, violence and misery on families and communities across Ireland is a top priority for the Government and An Garda Síochána.

The Deputy mentioned Garda resources. The Government is investing record amounts in An Garda Síochána to ensure the Garda Commissioner has the resources he needs to tackle the illegal drugs trade. A Garda budget of €2.59 billion for next year will fund the recruitment of up to 1,000 new gardaí, 200 more Garda staff and a doubling of the Garda Reserve to over 600 next year. A total of 794 garda recruits entered the Garda College across 2025, the largest intake in a year since 2018. Significant numbers of gardaí have attested from the Garda college throughout this year and as more probationary gardaí attest across 2026, all communities will see a benefit as they are assigned out to their stations.

Ultimately, the Commissioner will make the decision on where Garda resources are assigned but the Minister is assured that a number of factors are taken into account, including crime trends in an area, demographics and local resourcing requirements. I assure Deputy McCormack that in relation to the heinous and murderous act we saw at the weekend that resulted in the tremendously tragic and unacceptable loss of lives, no stone will be left unturned. Every avenue will be explored to make sure that those responsible are brought to justice.

I want to acknowledge the wider trauma surrounding this event. Another woman remains in hospital with serious injuries. Her life has been changed forever and she will need support in ways we cannot measure yet. I also want to acknowledge the first responders, gardaí, paramedics and Offaly fire service officers who entered that scene. They faced what most people could not. They acted with courage and humanity and they deserve recognition and support for the trauma they now carry quietly on behalf of us all. Neighbouring families are shaken. Children in the estate are frightened. Homes that should be now filled with Christmas excitement are instead filled with fear and unanswered questions that no parent should ever have to answer.

Edenderry Garda station does not operate on a 24-hour basis. Edenderry now needs reassurance through action by way of a visible policing presence and strengthened Garda numbers. Criminals do not operate on office hours and safety should not either. I ask that Edenderry Garda station would operate 24 hours a day. Let this tragedy be the moment that confidence is rebuilt in Edenderry, not the moment when we simply mourn or move on.

role.name: Minister of State at the Department of Culture, Communications and Sport

paragraphs: I join Deputy McCormack in extending my thoughts and prayers to the lady who was injured in the attack. I wish her a speedy recovery. Deputy McCormack's point in relation to Garda resources in Edenderry and Offaly is massively important. I understand that at the end of October, there were 399 gardaí assigned to the Laois-Offaly Garda division, a 45% increase on ten years ago. They are also supported by 51 Garda staff who provide really important support to gardaí and free them up to focus on front-line policing duties. Eight probationary gardaí were assigned to the Laois-Offaly Garda division this year and 12 probationers were assigned last year. It is also worth noting that An Garda Síochána operates a divisional model which means that it uses all of the resources within the division, not just the Garda station within a particular community, to respond to local demands on the service it provides.

We can see throughout our communities the damage and devastation that organised drug crime groups heap on society, not least in Deputy McCormack's local community over this past weekend. Tackling the issue of drug-related intimidation is a high priority for An Garda Síochána. Nominated Garda inspectors are available throughout the country through the drug-related intimidation reporting programme to assist victims of intimidation. In addition, the drug-related intimidation and violence engagement, DRIVE, project, which launched earlier this year has established effective systems for assisting those affected by drug-related intimidation. There are over 400 publicly-funded drugs services, including family support services, across the country which can advise and support people affected by drug-related intimidation. Family support services are critical because drug-related violence nearly always becomes an issue for the whole family. There is more information available for anyone who needs support on the [driveproject.ie] website

I thank Deputy McCormack again for raising this today and assure him that the Minister for Justice and Home Affairs and the Garda Commissioner will do everything they can do bring the people responsible to justice.

The warmer homes scheme is supposed to protect the most vulnerable households in our society, including older people, low-income families, people living alone and those wholly dependent on supports like the fuel allowance. Right now the scheme is failing them and it is about to get far worse. I will outline the current reality. On 4 November this year my office contacted the SEAI on behalf of a vulnerable client who applied for the warmer homes scheme in October 2024. Almost 14 months later she is still awaiting a survey or an allocation. The timelines are staggering. It is taking 14 months to get a survey, 26 months for works and another three months for post-works inspection. This is not a functioning scheme. We already have 20,000 homes on the waiting list. The Minister of State knows as well as I do that these are not discretionary upgrades. These are essential measures for people at risk of fuel poverty.

The critical point that I want to emphasise is that the number of people on the fuel allowance, the key qualifying criteria for the warmer homes scheme, is expanding dramatically. From next year those on the working family payment will be eligible. That is an additional 50,000 households, bringing the total number of fuel allowance recipients to more than 500,000. If nothing changes, the warmer homes scheme waiting list will surge even further because eligibility will expand faster than delivery capacity. This is not a projected problem; it is an inevitability. The SEAI currently has no action plan, no surge capacity, no backlog reduction strategy and no timeline for clearing the existing 20,000 cases. Money is not an issue but delivery is and telling people that we have increased funding is meaningless if funding does not translate into workers on roofs, contractors on the ground, insulation going into walls and people living in warmer homes.

When will a full, published action plan be produced to address the backlog of 20,000 homes? What contingency planning has been done for the additional 50,000 homes that will become eligible under the expanded fuel allowance scheme? Will the Government commit to a maximum six-month waiting time for a survey for any applicant on the fuel allowance? Will the Department intervene directly to ensure that the SEAI increases contractor and surveyor capacity immediately? We cannot keep telling vulnerable people to wait three winters for a warmer home. We cannot expand eligibility by 50,000 households while pretending the scheme can cope as it stands. This requires urgency, action and leadership now, not later.

role.name: Minister of State at the Department of Culture, Communications and Sport

paragraphs: I thank Deputy Murphy for raising this issue today. The climate action plan includes targets to retrofit the equivalent of 500,000 homes to a building energy rating, BER, of B2, cost optimal, and the installation of 400,000 heat pumps in existing homes to replace older, less efficient heating systems by the end of this decade. The national retrofit plan sets out the Government's approach to achieving those targets. The programme for Government 2025 contains a number of commitments in relation to retrofitting. They include delivering more B2 equivalent home retrofits each year from 2026 to 2030, with a focus on lower-income households, improving the provision of grants and financing models for home owners, including older people who wish to retrofit, enhancing energy efficiency and reducing costs, as well as supporting group retrofitting projects.

The warmer homes scheme aims to improve the energy efficiency and warmth of homes owned by people at risk of energy poverty by providing fully funded retrofits. The scheme is operated by the SEAI on behalf of the Department and is funded through carbon tax receipts and the European Regional Development fund, ERDF Last year saw a record spend of almost €230 million under the scheme.

As reported by the SEAI, this resulted in 7,743 upgrades being provided to lower-income households. This year's budget includes an allocation of €250 million for the scheme, which is a €50 million increase. That represents an elevenfold increase on the 2020 expenditure figure.

The scheme has been delivering a greater number of deeper and more complex upgrades in recent years, and this is reflected in the average cost of upgrades, which the SEAI indicates has increased from €2,600 in 2015 to over €29,000 this year. These deeper upgrades mean that more lower-income households are benefiting significantly from warmer, healthier and more comfortable homes with lower energy bills and reduced emissions.

With regard to waiting times, which I know are key to the point the Deputy is making, increased awareness of the multiple benefits of retrofit and improvement to the warmer homes scheme is driving increased levels of demand for the scheme, with just over 45,000 applications received over the period from January 2022 to the end of October 2025. Over the same period, more than 24,500 homes have been upgraded under the scheme. We had 45,000 applications and in the same period, 24,500 homes were upgraded.

For homes that have been allocated to a contractor for works under the scheme so far this year, the average waiting time was just under 15 months. Once a home is allocated to a contractor, the completion times can vary based on the types of works being undertaken at a home and the lead time for ordering and delivery of materials and products, such as windows, are factors. Homeowner availability for upgrades in their homes can also be a factor. The average waiting time from application to completion of upgrade works to date in 2025 has been 21 months for the worst performing homes and 22 months for better performing homes. It is important to note that these averages represent a significant reduction since the first half of 2022, when the average waiting time was 27.5 months.

The reduction in waiting times follows a range of measures introduced by the Department and the SEAI, including the allocation of additional staff to the warmer homes scheme, a significantly increased budget allocation and active contract engagement with management by the SEAI to increase contractor output, as well as actions to address ongoing supply chain pressures. A pilot delivering additional homes from the warmer homes scheme waiting list under the energy efficiency obligation scheme was introduced last year.

Importantly, the SEAI launched on 8 December a procurement process to establish a new €1.2 billion contractor panel to be in place by quarter 2 next year. This will support continued growth, with a focus on scale, quality and output under the scheme. Department officials continue to work with the SEAI to further accelerate and maximise the output of fully funded energy upgrades with the objective of minimising wait times.

I thank the Minister of State for his reply, which alluded to a 21-month waiting time. Correspondence sent to me directly by the SEAI confirmed that the waiting time is somewhere between 24 and 26 months. People came into my office in quarter 3 of 2024 and as of now, 14 months later, the SEAI cannot tell me when these homes will be surveyed. I have people in their 90s who applied in quarter 3 of 2024. They will not be alive when their house is due for a survey.

I appreciate the Minister of State's reply, but there is no concrete or time-bound plan. Nothing will change for people who are currently waiting for years for essential upgrades and insulation. I cannot understand why we cannot get the surveys done quicker. Not every house needs a heat pump or a new set of windows. Sometimes houses just need insulation. I cannot understand why we cannot deliver insulation upgrades within six months. The expansion of the fuel allowance to those on the working family payment would see a surge of 50,000 new houses qualifying for the warmer homes scheme. If we expand eligibility without expanding delivery capacity, we will simply deepen frustration, lengthen queues and worsen energy poverty.

There are, I say again, 20,000 homes on the waiting list. If nothing changes, these numbers will only go in one direction, which is upwards. I am telling the Minister of State that I will be here again next year and there will be 30,000 homes on the waiting list. It will take 16 or 18 months for a survey. It will take more than three years for full completion of works and vulnerable people cannot wait for three years. We need a backlog reduction task force, emergency procurement of surveyors and contractors and a fast-track system for the elderly and particularly high-risk households. This is about dignity, fairness and the basic right to a warm home. We need timelines, capacity and an action plan or the scheme will continue to fail the very people it was created to protect. People in their 90s who applied in quarter 3 of 2024 will not be alive when their houses are due for a survey.

role.name: Minister of State at the Department of Culture, Communications and Sport

paragraphs: I will relay the urgency of the need to increase the capacity to the Minister and the Department as a result of this debate. As I indicated in my previous contribution, we have seen a significant increase in the number of applicants. The number has gone from 3,000 homes in 2021 to 13,500 in 2024. There has been a massive increase in the number of applicants, which is obviously putting on pressure by way of demand. It is important that the capacity to deal with that and to deliver on this scheme matches the demand levels and the budget that has been allocated every year, which this year has increased, as I said earlier.

The other challenging factor that is influencing waiting time is the fact that deeper retrofits are taking place. That is reflected in the increase in cost from €2,500 ten years ago to €29,000 now. That is reflecting the fact that a lot more is happening whenever a retrofit is taking place.

The important piece, which will have a positive influence and will help to address the important point the Deputy is addressing, is the fact that the SEAI has put in place the procurement process for the new warmer homes contractor panel, which commenced in recent months. It is anticipated that it will attract additional capacity for the programme over the next four to five years. That tender carries an estimated value of €1.1 billion, representing a record programme of commitment for that five-year period. The SEAI expects to have the contractor panel in place for quarter 2. Its objective will be to support that continued growth with a focus on the scale, quality and output.

The SEAI also continuously monitors the performance of all contractors operating under the warmer homes scheme, including in relation to the quality, level of complaints, timelines and general administration.
I will certainly feed back the Deputy's key points to the Minister and the Department. I will emphasise the importance of ensuring that capacity continues to increase.
I thank the Minister of State from being here. She is from the relevant Department, and I appreciate it. That should be the norm in this House. It used to be.

An exceptional piece of journalism was published last week by the Limerick Leader. The front page article spoke about the catastrophic failures in University Hospital Limerick, UHL, which we have discussed in the House. No other topic have I discussed more in my political career. The picture on the front page shows four young women. I compliment the journalist, Ms Sandra Quinn, and the Limerick Leader for what they put out. Sometimes a visual says more than words. The story is about Ms Aoife Johnston and Ms Niamh McNally, both 16, Ms Eve Cleary, 21, and Ms Leona Cusack, who was 33. They all died because of what is going on in UHL.

I will say something of the Government with all the positivity I can. I know what I am talking about. I have spoken about my family in the Dáil on numerous occasions. I have spoken about my dad, the anniversary of whose passing was two days ago. He did not want to go into UHL. I have spoken about my neighbours and friends. I spoke recently about a situation where I had to ring and somebody in the HSE told me once I got on the motorway to go to Portlaoise hospital, which I did. That was an emergency and the patient got fantastic service. The Government has a huge decision to make. In fairness, the Minister, Deputy Carroll MacNeill, has said she will make that decision next week. She met mid-west Deputies and Senators two weeks ago. Unfortunately, for some reason, Deputy Sheehan and I were not invited so I must raise the issue on the floor of the Dáil.
The HIQA report was not necessary, but we have it because Mr. Gerry Burke, who was the former lead clinical consultant in UHL, did all the statistics ten years ago.
The situation has only got worse. Even in terms of the HIQA report, the census data is out of date. We are totally discriminated against.

If you look at the south east, which the Minister of State is very familiar with, there are three model 4 hospitals in Waterford, Wexford and Kilkenny. There is also one in south Tipperary. We have one. That is not sustainable. The idea that the people in Clare, Limerick and north Tipperary have only one accident and emergency for 450,000 people is insane. The only decision that can be made next week, along with option A of the 96-bed block and option B of building a 100-bed unit nearby, is to make the decision long term. We need ambition to have a model 3 or model 4 hospital in the mid-west. Anything else will continue this discrimination and I will not be part of another generation of politicians who stand up in this House and accept that.

It is discrimination. My phone was ringing all weekend about cases in Limerick. Despite the new 96-bed block, the numbers there are 110 on trolleys and 31,000 on waiting lists. We have a worrying situation where consultants, because of the working conditions, are leaving. I urge the Minister of State to give the Christmas news everybody in Tipperary, Limerick, Clare and even parts of north Cork want to hear and that is that we will do all the short- and medium-term planning and we will look again at the pathways regarding minor injury units and open them up as well as open up community services but for God's sake, we need another hospital in the mid-west. It is as plain as the nose on my face. Any other decision is discrimination and is totally wrong. I will be the first person to stand up and congratulate the Minister of State if she delivers it.

role.name: Minister of State at the Department of Health

speeches.speakerLabel: Minister of State at the Department of Health (Deputy Mary Butler)
paragraphs: I thank Deputy Kelly for the opportunity to address the House on the discussion around the need for a new model 4 hospital in the mid-west region. I also thank him for his ongoing advocacy in relation to University Hospital Limerick. I have stood across the floor from him many times over the past five and half years discussing health matters, and he has been very consistent. I want to put that on the record.

In May 2024, HIQA was requested to conduct a review of urgent and emergency care in the mid-west region, with the primary objective of ensuring safe, quality, acute care. As part of this review, HIQA was requested to consider the case for a second emergency department in the context of the population changes in the region and with the ongoing pressures at UHL. HIQA submitted its final report to the Minister, and it was published on 30 September this year.

As the Deputy will appreciate, the reports and analysis supporting this review are extensive. There was substantial stakeholder engagement, regulatory inspections, a national policy review, data analysis review and international evidence reviews. The Minister and I acknowledge the substantial work undertaken by all those who both conducted and took part in this review, including the expert advisory group which included a wide representation of relevant experience.

In summary, HIQA’s analysis found the inpatient bed capacity in the region needed to be increased to meet current and projected demand for patients requiring more complex or specialist healthcare. I acknowledge UHL is still the busiest hospital, with a 10% increase in attendance this year compared to the last year. I had a conversation with senior management this morning and they are on track to receive 100,000 attendees to the emergency department this year. Mitigation pieces are in place regarding senior clinician decision-making and de-escalation of the emergency department, with a good length of stay averaging at four and half days. Thankfully, mortality is static and currently in line with every other hospital.

I recently visited the mid-west region to discuss mental health and I compliment the mental health teams. The CAMHS teams there have turned around the complete waiting list and are now operating much better. I also visited University Hospital Limerick and met with the regional executive officer, Sandra Broderick, and senior management. I visited the new 96-bed block and I am delighted to say it is open, which the Deputy has welcomed publicly. The second one will be up and running as soon as possible. However, this does not solve the short-term issues.

This morning there are 32 people on trolleys in UHL - three in the emergency department and 29 moved to wards. This is similar to other areas. In Galway, there are 51, in Cork, there are 39, and in the Mater, there are 27. Certainly, every focus has been put in place to try to reduce that.

Going back to the HIQA report, it presents three options, as the Deputy knows, with the expansion of capacity at UHL on the Dooradoyle site, which is option A; the extension of the UHL hospital campus to include a second site in close proximity, which is option B; and option C, which is the development of a model 3 hospital in HSE Mid West. The Minister has accepted the report and the advice from HIQA. Along with her officials, she is considering the comprehensive and detailed reports and advice provided by HIQA and will report back to Government before the end of the year.
The ESRI has projected the number of inpatient beds to meet the projected 2040 demand will need to increase from between 299 and 593 beds compared with 2023 capacity levels.

I thank the Minister of State for her response and I acknowledge the improvements that have happened in UHL in the past couple of years. However, we have serious issues when it comes to staffing and high-level consultants as regards attracting them, given the situation the hospital is in.

Politics has failed the people of the mid-west on this issue. I am not going to start blaming certain parties but politics has failed across this House. Consultants helped drive the agenda to close the units in Ennis, St. John's and Nenagh. Then, they disappeared off the face of the earth and were never found again. Politics now has to come back and fix it. This Chamber has to fix it; the Minister of State's Department has to fix it. We cannot fail the people of the mid-west continuously as we head into Christmas again, with people who live alongside me afraid. We cannot fail the families of these four poor women and others. I could give the Minister of State hundreds of examples of issues there.

The Minister of State spoke about the volume of beds required, which I absolutely accept but how in the name of God can we create those beds without creating a new hospital? I am not even arguing for Nenagh, Ennis or wherever; I just want a decision that we need a new hospital in the mid-west - an access point with beds and critical infrastructure. We cannot go on the way we are. We need that ambition and I am afraid this is being choreographed, that the decision being made next week will be options A and B but not C. I have no issue with option B as long as that decision to create another 100 beds has a hospital wrapped around it in years to come.

The Minister for public expenditure is from the Minister of State's party. I urge the Ministers for Health and public expenditure, Deputies Carroll MacNeill and Chambers, in the next week before the Cabinet decision is made - it has to be made because the Minister has promised it - that this decision will be long term and that we will create a new model 3 or 4 hospital in the mid-west to end the discrimination and fear. There are people who will not go into UHL because of the fear they have and the situation we have been left in.

role.name: Minister of State at the Department of Health

paragraphs: I thank the Deputy for that. The Minister will update her Cabinet colleagues before Christmas on her considered response. I acknowledge the fact the Deputy appreciates there is work going on to increase capacity and additional funding has been provided. UHL's budget has increased from €265 million in 2019 to €507 million in 2024. I will also touch on the two rapid build 16-bed units opened in December 2024 and June 2025, respectively, and the 96-bed block that was opened in October 2025, which the Deputy spoke about, to provide an additional 128 beds in the region, since the ESRI assessment of capacity in 2023. This has already helped reduce the number of people waiting on trolleys, notwithstanding the pressures all hospitals are currently facing due to the increased presentations by people sick with the flu. A second new 96-bed block is in progress at UHL and a third 16-bed block is planned for 2026.

Bed capacity has been further expanded throughout the region, through the acute hospital inpatient bed capacity expansion plan, including 24 new beds at Nenagh Hospital, 48 new beds at Ennis Hospital and 42 new beds at St. John's Hospital.

It is expected that there will be at least an additional 420 beds in the region by 2031. Other initiatives for the region include the acute virtual ward for 25 patients, which went live in UHL in July 2024. I will also touch on the staff, especially those working in the emergency department with the constantly increasing presentations every day. They are the front line and do a phenomenal job.

However, I take on board every word the Deputy said. I know people are waiting in anticipation for the Minister's response. She has said she will bring it to the Cabinet before Christmas and I will speak to her after this debate to let her know about the Deputy's strength of feeling. Everyone accepts and acknowledges that there is not enough capacity of acute hospital beds in the region at the moment. I thank the Deputy again for his advocacy.

I wish to raise the long delays in a rebuild project that three schools in my constituency are facing. They are St. John Bosco Junior Boys School, St. John Bosco Senior Boys School and Mary, Help of Christians Girls National School. These schools are just off the Navan Road in Dublin 7. They serve the communities of Ashtown, Navan Road and such new communities as Pelletstown. They are great schools. I have had the opportunity to visit them. I have met the student council of St. John Bosco school and I had the chance to see just how run-down those old buildings were. They are musty, prefabricated buildings with single-glazed windows and cold classrooms.

They are three distinct schools, but they have come together with a vision for an education campus on the site. The Minister of State will be aware that bringing three separate schools together under one project is a challenge, but such is the commitment of the school management teams that they have done it. They have a definitive plan for how the students would move out of sections of the old school, how those sections would be demolished and how the new school would be built across the site over a period. However, there has been a real blockage in the schools getting past the notorious stage 2a of the Department's processes. This was an election issue in the general election this time last year and, as soon as I was re-elected, I asked a parliamentary question of the then Minister in February this year. There was due to be a meeting between the schools and the Department back in March. That was cancelled quite abruptly.

The situation to date is that the Department requested a stage 2a addendum report from the school's design team, which advised the Department at least four weeks in advance of that report that it would come in on 30 October 2025. Despite having significant notice from the school design team, the Department did not allocate any time or resources to review the documentation when it was received. A meeting had been scheduled by the design team with the Department in anticipation of progressing the review, but again, the Department cancelled the meeting and informed the schools the documentation would now not be examined until after the new year. This is extremely disappointing, particularly given the three schools were explicitly assured that this project would move to the next phase in the first quarter of this year.

I acknowledge that the Department sought additional detail and amendments through the addendum, but the lack of preparation on the Department's side to review that documentation when it came in raises serious concerns. I know and the school knows that the Department school building team is under real pressure, but it is now more than a year that these schools have not been able to get past stage 2a. The school and its design team are working quickly and efficiently and are keeping the Department up to date on progress at every stage. However, the Department is not replicating that level of engagement. These three schools, St. John Bosco Junior Boys School, St. John Bosco Senior Boys School and Mary, Help of Christians Girls National School, need a firm date as early as possible from the Department on which to meet the design team, agree the addendum report and let these schools progress to the next stage. Can the Minister of State give me a firm date for when this meeting will take place?

role.name: Minister of State at the Department of Culture, Communications and Sport

paragraphs: I thank the Deputy. I am taking this Topical Issue matter on behalf of the Minister for Education and Youth, Deputy Naughton, to outline to the Dáil the current position of the joint school project for St. John Bosco Junior Boys School, St. John Bosco Senior Boys School and Mary, Help of Christians Girls National School in Dublin 7. The joint school building project the Deputy outlined the background of will deliver two new 16-classroom primary schools, with additional classrooms for children with special educational needs for the senior boys school and the girls school and a new 11-classroom primary school with additional classrooms for children with special educational needs for the junior boys school.

Initially, it was anticipated that this joint project would be delivered in the form of an extension and refurbishment. However, due to a scope change to include an increase of classrooms for children with special educational needs, it was decided that new school buildings would be provided. The design team submitted the initial stage 1 report in April 2023 and, following the submission of an addendum report in August of that year, the project was approved to move to the next stage.

The design team submitted its stage 2a submission report to the Department in January 2024 for review. Upon review, some key concerns were identified by departmental officials and the school authorities and design team were advised in advance that, in place of the stakeholders meeting, there would be a further interim stage 2a workshop to discuss and assist the design team in progressing its stage 2a submission in a positive manner. The design team was asked to complete a review and audit of the floor area schedules and to refine some design elements in order to meet the approved schedule of accommodation. A further interim workshop was held on 22 March 2024 between the Department and the design team architect, where further refinements and adjustment to floor area were discussed.

Upon receipt of the revised stage 2a report, departmental officials carried out an initial review and arranged an architectural workshop with the design team lead in May of this year to discuss it further. In early June 2025, a further meeting was held with the wider design team, school authorities and departmental officials in attendance. At that meeting, the school was provided with a progress update and advised that the design team was due to submit an addendum stage 2a report to the Department. The outstanding information for the addendum stage 2a report was received in the Department on 31 October 2025. Departmental officials will carry out a full review of the addendum report and the stakeholders' meeting will be scheduled once the review is completed.

In July, the Government announced a capital allocation of €7.55 billion for the Department of Education and Youth for the period 2026 to 2030 under the national development plan, NDP. As part of this NDP allocation, the Department will place a strong emphasis on provision for children with special educational needs, with a particular focus on meeting annual school place needs. The approach to project roll-out for large-scale projects and additional school accommodation scheme projects will be to continue to maximise the capacity of the existing school estate as much as possible in the first instance and provide necessary additional capacity through targeted and prioritised project roll-out over the course of the 2026-30 period to meet the most urgent and prioritised needs.

I thank the Minister of State for the update, but I am disappointed that he, or the Department of Education and Youth, is not in a position to give a clear date for when the schools' design team will meet the Department to, first, discuss the latest addendum report submitted by the schools and, second, give them permission to move past stage 2a. In the speech the Minister of State read, we see that the initial stage 1 report was submitted in April 2023 and it was followed by a stage 2a submission report in January 2024 and a workshop in March 2024, and then we jump to another workshop in May 2025. My concern is that this is not progressing with the degree of haste the situation in these schools requires.
